Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Baked plum, licorice and lavender aromas and flavors define this jammy wine, which takes on a sweetness of oak. Thick on the midpalate, it has substantial weight from the tannins and powerfully ripe fruit.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Gilsson Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Pomegranate and light baking-spice aromas show on the mellow nose of this bottling. The palate is clean with fruit punch and spice-cake flavors wrapped in a fairly mellow texture.
Wine: Wente 2014 Coastal Selection Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Review: Butter and vanilla notes dominate the jammy fruit flavors in this rich and seemingly sweet wine. It is medium bodied, lightly tannic and heavily influenced by oaky aromas and flavors, including baking spices and maple syrup.
Wine: California Republic 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Review: An aroma like toasted almonds and wood smoke meets spiced plum and red-cherry flavors in this medium-bodied wine. It's an oaky version that maintains pretty good balance.
Wine: Collier Creek 2015 Red Wagon Pinot Noir (Lodi)

Review: Plum skin and pomegranate lead the nose while white pepper and raw oak take on an earthy edge. The soft-bodied palate is awash in silky tannins, with intense flavors of vanilla, oak and green tobacco leaf over black cherry and plum. There is a spicy kick on the finish, with more vanilla and baked black plum.
Wine: DiLuca 2016 Rosso Black Label Red

Review: This is a big ripe red wine moderate in structure that offers fleshy mouthfuls of cola and black cherry.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Thomas Road Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 48% Cabernet Sauvignon and 38% Merlot, with the balance Malbec and Petit Verdot. Aromas of mushroom, dried herb, wet gravel, spice and cherry lead to ripe cherry and soy flavors. The palate brings a sense of elegance and appeal.
Wine: Gordon Estate 2014 Estate Grown Traditions Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Honey-dipped pineapple and guava, with a touch of fig give this wine a fruity midpalate. This has a moderate structure and a lingering note of anise.
Wine: K Squared Cellars 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma County)

Review: Thick and oaky, this estate wine evokes caramel and pineapple-upside-down cake—its texture lushly unctuous and rich.
Wine: Kunde 2016 C.S. Ridge Estate Grown Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With an ashy undercurrent of char and smoke, this wine offers medium-bodied layers of dried cherry and leather, finishing with a lasting note of black pepper.
Wine: Mengler Family Wines 2016 Alegria Vineyards Sangiovese (Russian River Valley)

Review: Dusty with highlights of cedar and sage, this full-bodied wine presents as somewhat dull on the palate—a soft, rounded and approachable expression of jammy blueberry.
Wine: Bravante 2013 Cabernet Franc (Howell Mountain)

Review: Yellow apple and sweet oak aromas make for a pleasant if not particularly complex aromatic entry to this bottling. Ripe apple and pear meet with sweet buttercream on the palate.
Wine: Esser 2016 Chardonnay (Monterey County)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a full-bodied, boldly ripe Cabernet Sauvignon. Soft layers of dark cherry and plum are well integrated and contrasted against dusty crushed rock and toasted oak.
Wine: Kirkland Signature 2015 Signature Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Review: A deep shade of pink, this bottling from Pinot Noir grapes shows very subtle red-fruit aromas on the nose. There is decent texture on the sip, but the flavors are muddled and slightly rusty.
Wine: Malibu Rocky Oaks 2017 Rosé (Central Coast)

Review: Aromas of ripe blueberry and blackberry mingle with vanilla and pumpkin spice on the nose. The fruit forward palate shows plum and cranberry backed by dried leaves, nutmeg and vanilla. The tannins are dusty yet structured, while the acidity is tied to the berry flavors and weaves in and out. It finishes with a tart berry flavor loaded with cracked pepper and earthy.
Wine: Messina Hof 2015 Private Reserve Double Barrel Merlot (Texas)

Review: Brawny fruit is overwhelmed by smoke and charred oak in this thickly tannic wine that has a jammy core of blackberry and marshmallow flavor.
Wine: Murphy-Goode 2014 Liar's Dice Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Review: Pear, butter and vanilla aromas lead to a soft, rich texture and tasty fruit flavors. The wine is medium in weight, low in acidity and easy on the palate.
Wine: Oak Grove 2017 Family Reserve Chardonnay (California)

Review: This is an easygoing, fruity wine that shows sweet-oak aromas, a soft texture and candy-like flavors of cherries and raspberries. The body is medium, tannins are light and it finishes with a sense of sweetness.
Wine: Old Soul 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Review: This has a wealth of cherry cola flavor that brushes up against varietal black currant and cedar. It takes on a lush brawny ripeness that overwhelms and opts for fruit flavor over structure.
Wine: Raymond 2015 LVE Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral and quite cherry-berry in fruity flavor, this wine has mild structure and generous tannin, with a midpalate bursting in earthy oak.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Battaglini Vineyard Ancient Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very extracted aromas of red currants and all spice show on the ripe nose of this bottling. Muddled plums and berries meet with spice cake on the rich palate.
Wine: Balderdash 2014 Joyride Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This big and rather tart wine has a green streak in the piney, woody aromas and flavors that accompany red-cherry and sour-cherry notes.
Wine: Binz 2016 Oleta Vineyard Barbera (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Rustic and hearty in style, this medium-bodied wine has earthy aromas, strong acidity and flavors like peach skin and grapefruit rind.
Wine: Briceland 2017 Spirit Canyon Vineyard Arneis (Mendocino County)

Review: This wine has fresh fruit flavors and a fair share of vanilla and nutmeg from aging with oak. It feels smooth, medium bodied and soft in structure as little tannin comes through.
Wine: Carson Scott 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Boasting overripe aromas and flavors of raisins and dried cherries, this wine is full bodied and very broad.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2014 Estate Reserve Cabernet Franc (Fair Play)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an austere, earthy and tannic red tangy in strawberry and dark cherry with a lingering taste of hazelnut and oak.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2015 Karmen Isabella Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of green pepper, black currant, plum and spice are at the fore. The flavors are reserved in style, not staying together throughout but still providing some appeal.
Wine: Gordon Estate 2015 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Yellow peach and Mandarin orange peel are shy on the nose. The palate offers bright acidity and flavors of ripe yellow peach, pear, white flower and chalk. Lemon and orange flavors finish with a chalky texture.
Wine: Grape Creek Vineyards 2016 Cuvée Blanc White (Texas)

Review: This wine possesses a hearty helping of tannin and herbal elements that won't appeal to all. Full bodied and concentrated in ripeness, the dried herbs and cedar dominate on the nose and palate. Small amounts of Petit Verdot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec are blended in.
Wine: Gundlach Bundschu 2015 Merlot (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Redwood Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: An especially bright copper color make this wine stand out visually, while tart fruit flavors and a very dry crisp texture complete the picture. Moderate in alcohol, it has a lean taste profile, too.
Wine: Jigar 2017 Tollini Vineyard Grenache Rosé (Redwood Valley)

Review: This wine has a touch of reduction that makes it hard to fully delve into, a well as a thickly tannic character of ripeness that quietly exudes notions of blackberry and vanilla.
Wine: Saddleback 2016 Old Vines Zinfandel (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 38% Merlot, 31% Cabernet Franc, 25% Cabernet Sauvignon and 6% Petit Verdot. Aromas of dried cherry and baking spice lead to tangy, somewhat green seeming fruit flavors that drop off on the finish.
Wine: Auclair 2016 96 Cedars Red (Red Mountain)

Review: This medium-bodied wine shows a lot of oak influence in the baking-spice aromas, cedar and vanilla flavors and spicy finish. Under the oak are bright raspberry and cherry flavors.
Wine: Binz 2016 Barbera (Sierra Foothills)

Review: Obvious oak aromas and an almost sweet sensation on the palate give this wine a sense of wearing plenty of makeup. The texture is broad and soft, and the flavors are like candied cherries.
Wine: Caricature 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Clarksburg)

Review: Red cherry and turned earth show on the simple but clean nose of this bottling. Tart red fruit and more dusty qualities show on the sip, with a hint of vanilla on the finish.
Wine: Esser 2016 Merlot (Monterey County)

Review: Cut grass and pungent green-apple slices make for a familiar entry to the nose of this bottling. The palate starts with Granny Smith apple and nectarine flavors, but they are short-lived and the texture is flat.
Wine: Esser 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Monterey County)

Review: Aromas of black plum, ripe raspberry, violet, bay leaf, fresh thyme and black pepper spice are savory on the nose. The palate shows tart cranberry and black cherry, with an earthy, herbal undertow. The tannins are soft textured but very drying, while the acidity is tangy with an underripe berry flavor. A leathery tone is introduced on the finish, while the tannins hug the tip of the tongue.
Wine: Haak 2016 Touriga Nacional (Texas High Plains)

Review: This Viognier is nutty on the nose. A hints of an underripe papaya aroma is followed by a tangy impression on the palate. Oily in feel and full in body, the finish is long and flabby.
Wine: Jefferson Vineyards 2017 Viognier (Virginia)

Review: This is a showy brash wine that smells smoky and oaky, has medium body and tastes like wood char, cranberries and vanilla. Not much varietal character comes through but it will please oak lovers.
Wine: Klinker Brick 2015 Carignane (Lodi)

Review: This wine opens gritty in texture and tannin before softening on the midpalate. Black fruit, cedar, dried herb and black pepper combine for a forceful experience of power and serious ripeness.
Wine: La Storia 2016 Block 303 Zinfandel (Alexander Valley)

Review: This is a sweet but light-bodied dessert-style wine that will taste great with cheese, desserts that aren't too sweet, or on its own. It has floral aromas and flavors like apricots and tutti-frutti ice cream, but it also has good acidity to keep it balanced.
Wine: LangeTwins 2017 Estate Grown Moscato (Clarksburg)

Review: Toast, plum, herb and cherry aromas are followed by light, slightly sweet seeming fruit flavors. The tannins seem quite bunched up, not appearing to have fully ripened, and the fruit concentration a bit light.
Wine: Luke 2016 Merlot (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The aromas of cedar and cigar box consume the dark fruit on the nose of this bottling. Similar wood-spice and pine-oil flavors are wrapped around the palate, with flashes of black plum and tobacco trying to emerge.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2015 J.D. Hurley Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: The nose shows ripe black plum, blackberry, herbs and stale pepper, while the palate offers blueberry, raspberry, oak and cocoa powder. The cranberry-laced finish displays the easygoing grip of crushed-velvet tannins.
Wine: McPherson 2015 Tempranillo (Texas)

Review: This Texas Sémillon offers a chalky nose that blends with fresh clementine, lime and pine needles. The light palate is somewhat creamy due to rounded acidity, presenting flavors of lemon juice, crushed stone and a touch of lemongrass. There is some mineral-driven astringency on the finish alongside citrus and white pepper.
Wine: Messina Hof 2017 Private Reserve Sémillon (Texas High Plains)

Review: A rather deep copper color and a combination of savory and fruity flavors make this medium-bodied wine a little more serious and substantial than many. It's made from red Rhône varietals.
Wine: Resign 2017 Rosé (California)

Review: This vineyard-designate has a sweet nose of oak and corresponding thick ripe richness on the palate—a full-bodied take that's generous in tannin and flavors of vanilla and coconut.
Wine: Rocca 2014 Grigsby Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)

Review: A heavy oak influence gives this full-bodied wine smoky, charred aromas and flavors that dampen the fruity components that may have been in the grapes. It's bold and spicy.
Wine: Blue Victorian Winery 2016 Barbera (Suisun Valley)

Review: A deep, dark color and deep, dark flavors steal the show in this extra-ripe and extremely spicy wine. Oak is the star, as cedar, clove, vanilla, cinnamon and smoke notes pervade the aromas, flavors and finish.
Wine: Carnivor 2016 Zinfandel (California)

Review: Soft-textured and definitely fruity, this easy-going non-oaky wine is charming for its fresh raspberry aromas and red-fruit flavors. The texture is smooth and non-tannic.
Wine: Collier Creek 2016 Old Press Zinfandel (Lodi)

Review: Quite light in the glass, this twist-top bottling shows hints of hibiscus, cranberry and damp herbs on the nose. The palate offers tart flavors of tomato and orange rind, lifted by fresh herbs.
Wine: Formation 2015 Pinot Noir (Monterey)

Review: Fresh honeydew, aloe and juniper flavors mingle in this medium-bodied Vidal Blanc, while the nose is fainter, with soft notes of lemon and limestone. There's a sweetness to the wine, but it's tempered by a spicy strain that helps keep it aloft. This is an easy, approachable wine.
Wine: Gray Ghost 2017 Vidal Blanc (Virginia)

Review: This is a soft, open wine, lightly flavored with raspberry and dried sage. This is a fun wine, marked by frail bubbles and light acidity.
Wine: Horton NV Erotes Sparkling (Virginia)

Review: Aromas of orange blossoms, lemon peels and yellow apples are pleasant on the nose. The palate offers ripe orange, lime juice and lime leaves, but the dry finish is astringent and sweeps away those juicy citrus flavors.
Wine: Llano Estacado 2017 Signature Series Pinot Grigio (Texas)

Review: Aromas of lemon oil and citrus blossom are wrapped in an herbal haze on the nose of this Sauvignon Blanc that's blended with 23% Chenin Blanc and 1% each of Marsanne and Viognier. The palate is dry and astringent, with spry lemon-lime acidity and flavors of ripe apple, blossoms and a whisper of salinity.
Wine: Llano Estacado 2017 Signature Series Sauvignon Blanc (Texas)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Light aromas of cherry, vanilla and spice lead to full-bodied fruit flavors backed by dry, grippy tannins that come off as quite aggressive out of the gate but calm down a bit with a day open.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Vineyard Series McKinley Springs Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)

Review: Floral and herbal, this wine offers bright, persistent acidity around a full-bodied embrace of ripe peach and pineapple.
Wine: Maxville 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: Blueberry and black raspberry aromas are slightly overripe on the nose. The palate remains ripe in feel, with baked blueberry and tart cranberry. Oaky tones add weight and dusty tannins quickly sweep in, somewhat smothering the flavors. The finish is mild and slightly bitter.
Wine: McPherson 2016 EVS Windblown Red (Texas High Plains)

Review: The aromas of this medium-bodied wine overflow with apples and peaches, and the flavors are crisp, fruity and clean. The mouthfeel is rather rich for the varietal and backed by a nip of good acidity.
Wine: Parducci 2017 Small Lot Pinot Gris (Mendocino)

Review: This white offers aromas of white flowers, orange peels, apricots and peaches that mingle with notes of grass and white pepper. The palate has a creamy mouthfeel, rounding out flavors of lemonade, white peach juice, lemon balm and gooseberry. The orange oil finish has a faint bitter lime edge.
Wine: Pedernales 2015 Albariño (Texas)

Review: An earthy, buttery aroma leads to warm peach and spice flavors. This wine has a nicely rich texture and is light on fruitiness and acidity.
Wine: The Seeker 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Review: This wine is fruity in nature, with soft tannins, oak spice and red-berry flavors. It has a juicy aftertaste that blends with the fruitiness.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Tannat (Virginia)

Review: Strong lemon-peel, Pink Lady apple and orange-blossom aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The palate starts slightly sweet and grows much sweeter toward the finish, with ripe pear and apple flavors, but not much acidity.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2016 Orange Muscat (California)

Review: A broadly defined, simply structured white, this has expansive richness on the palate and measured acidity on offer. Green apple, lime and lemon custard provide varietal character.
Wine: WindVane 2016 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Carneros)

Review: This medium-bodied wine has good fresh fruit flavors that verge on jammy, boosted by a sweet-seeming oak character that includes vanilla, maple and brown sugar accents. It's smooth in texture and light in tannin content for this varietal.
Wine: Telios 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Baking spice, vanilla, licorice and dried cherry aromas are followed by dried-out-seeming fruit flavors. Dry tannins and cranberry flavors fill it out. It seems quite evolved for its age.
Wine: Auclair 2015 Heart of the Hill Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Overextracted aromas of tangy black plum and blackberry jam show on the nose of this bottling. Ripe flavors of black-plum juice prove too tangy and nearly vinegar-like.
Wine: Balderdash 2014 49 Mulberry Merlot (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of soil, violet, herb and cherry lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that trail on the finish. It seems slightly evolved for its age.
Wine: Gordon Estate 2014 Estate Grown Petit Verdot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Pear and apricot aromas are joined by a soapy gardenia note. The palate is ripe and loaded with peach, guava, lemon and rose. Blood orange acidity moves to a finish of apple and blossoms.
Wine: Landon 2016 Bingham Family Vineyards Viognier (Texas)

Review: This light-bodied wine is grassy in aroma, has lean veggie and lemon flavors and a fairly crisp mouthfeel.
Wine: LangeTwins 2017 Estate Grown Musqué Clone Sauvignon Blanc (Lodi)

Review: A floral and herbal nose delivers rose, white pepper and lime. The palate offers plenty of acidity but is gentle and soft in feel, with ripe lime and grapefruit flavors that are rounded out by a blossomy note. A dry, citrus finish shows astringent acidity and a white pepper tone.
Wine: Messina Hof 2017 Dry Style Pinot Blanc (Texas)

Review: An abundance of sweet-seeming, spicy oak fills the aroma and smothers the fruit flavors in this spice cabinet of a wine. It has lots of vanilla, ginger, nutmeg and maple flavors and full body.
Wine: Moss Roxx 2015 Ancient Vine Reserve Zinfandel (Lodi)

Review: Light-red fruit, crushed gravel and a hint of gunmetal aromas show on the nose of this bottling. It's lighter bodied on the palate with lots of turned soil flavors and just a touch of red fruit.
Wine: Olelo 2016 Merlot (Paso Robles)

Review: A slightly darker shade of yellow in the glass, this bottling shows dried apple, wet hay and orange touches on the nose. The palate offers apple, pear and lime flavors, but without much texture or energy.
Wine: Ballard Lane 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Review: There is beautiful packaging on this bottle, yet it contains less-than-beautiful wine. Aromas of vinegar-laced cranberry sauce leads into tangy cooked cranberry flavors on the sip.
Wine: Dirt Diva 2015 Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This wine has a pink tinge in the color and strong floral and fruity aromas. It is peachy in flavor, light in body and slightly sweet, making it an aromatic, picnic-style wine.
Wine: Farmhouse 2017 White (California)

Review: Perfumed notes of rose and lily are joined by lime zest and candied orange on the nose of this refreshing, but simple Riesling. On the light footed and playful palate there is an orange flavored sweetness throughout, with notes of tart green apple, ripe lemon and pear. There are some chalky, mineral notes that quietly add depth to the palate, while ripe grapefruit and lime round out the finish.
Wine: Grape Creek Vineyards 2016 Riesling (Texas)

Review: Golden in color, this wine opens bright and fresh on the nose before providing a lush, creamy and fruit-forward experience of indelible ripeness on the palate.
Wine: Kenwood 2017 Pinot Gris (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A rusty shade of pink, this bottling, which includes 10% Picpoul Blanc, shows cooked cherries and baking spice on the nose. The palate is full of watery cherries.
Wine: Kula 2017 Rosé of Syrah (Paso Robles)

Review: A fairly dark shade of rusty gold in the glass, this bottling starts with aromas of toasted nuts and baked bread. The palate comes across more fresh, showing tangy lemon rind, unsweetened iced tea and more nutty qualities.
Wine: Lovingston 2016 Janet's Block Chardonnay (Monticello)

Review: This is a good, basic wine with modest amounts of fruitiness and butteriness mingling on a medium body. A chalky, earthy note comes in on the midpalate and lingers.
Wine: Viaggio 2016 Buttercup Chardonnay (Lodi)

Review: Light in color and flavor, this wine smells tangy and citrus-like, and tastes lean and low in fruit and acidity. It's clean and simple in character.
Wine: Fetzer 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (California)

Review: This wine seems sweet due to candied-fruit aromas and flavors and oaky spices like vanilla and maple. It is medium bodied and soft in texture for the varietal.
Wine: Jack's House 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Review: The nose offers aromas of Marasca cherry, candied orange and sharp angostura bitters over subtler tones of sawdust and aged oak. Fairly tart upfront in flavors of plum and red cherry, the palate is bolstered by sandy tannins and tangy acidity.
Wine: Llano Estacado 2014 THP Montepulciano (Texas High Plains)

Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: High-toned apple and cherry aromas are followed by a scratchy feeling palate marked by gritty tannins. The tannins don't seem to have fully ripened, and the variety is hard to find.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Elephant Mountain Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Rattlesnake Hills)

Review: Aromas of peppercorns, earthy licorice, pumpernickel and black currant are intriguing on the nose of this blend of 45% Syrah, 35% Mourvèdre and 22% Grenache. Ripe fruit flavors are propped up by juicy acidity over sandy tannins. This remains juicy towards the finish, with a touch of peppery spice.
Wine: Messina Hof NV G-S-M (Texas)

Review: Muted in a nutty aroma, this approachable wine doesn't offer much in fruity or floral notes. It shows a lighter take on the palate as well, where lemon, almond skin and lees tones are subdued. Soft and thin in mouthfeel, it has a short, but friendly finish.
Wine: Gray Ghost 2017 Chardonnay (Virginia)

Review: This wine is viscous and sweetly ripe in baked apple and honey flavors, with a thickness that persists.
Wine: Hailstone Vineyards 2017 32 Degrees Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: Tight aromas of banana, white grape and juniper show on the nose of this Viognier. The ripe yet racy palate is framed by decent acidity, while delivering flavors of pastille candies and melon.
Wine: Jefferson Vineyards 2017 Jefferson's Own Estate Reserve Viognier (Monticello)

Review: This is a good picnic wine to serve with cheese or salty snacks. It's sweet, smooth and very fruity, with medium body, low alcohol and soft acidity.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2017 Jessie's Collection Orange Muscat (California)

Review: Aromas of Satsuma, lychee, gooseberry and lily are luscious and inviting. A burst of sweetness paired with zesty acidity quickly mellows into soft ripe flavors of honeydew melon, white peach and lychee. The palate is creamy in feel, with some tangy acidity on the fringe to balance it out. Ripe yellow peach and sweet Valencia orange linger on the finish.
Wine: Llano Estacado 2017 Gewürztraminer (Texas)

Review: The aromas seem muddled, needing more clarity. The palate drinks medium-plus sweet, with peach and orange flavors. It doesn't all come together, living off the sugar.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: This wine offers jammy blueberry and lavender aromas that are tinged with brett. The palate brings high-octane flavors, supported by racy acidity that both demand more tannic structure and complexity in mouthfeel.
Wine: James Charles 2017 Cabernet Sauvignon (Virginia)

Review: Aromas of fur, rubber and black plum take on a feral character. Concentrated tannins are a brutish gatekeeper, settling on the front of the palate ahead of flavors of black plum, cassis, vanilla and baking spice. The tannins are the guiding force through the spicy finish that carries nutmeg and black fruit.
Wine: Llano Estacado 2014 1836 Red (Texas)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas offer notes of toast, spice and dark fruit. Despite the higher alcohol level, the flavors are somewhat lighter in style, a touch sweet but straight down the fairway, with a tangy finish. It's a straightforward, easy drinker.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Vineyard Series Clifton Hill Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is simple in structure with a medium-bodied richness of juicy red fruit.
Wine: Merriam 2013 Windacre Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Russian River Valley)

Review: This medium-bodied wine has an earthy overtone at first sip and then generally ripe and plummy flavors that are straightforward but lightly accented by vanilla. It feels smooth in texture.
Wine: Seven Daughters 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Review: Gentle in texture and in flavor, this wine is medium bodied, rather soft in mouthfeel and has ripe strawberry and raspberry notes. The finish is pleasant but short.
Wine: Slater Run 2017 Cabernet Franc (Virginia)

Review: Perfumed and floral aromas are joined by lychee, citrus and sugar plum on the nose. Lemon juice and grapefruit pith are highlighted by pineapple acidity, florals and grassiness on the straightforward palate, finishing with lemon pith and wet stone.
Wine: Alba 2016 Dry Riesling (Warren Hills)

Review: This wine tastes slightly underripe, with herbal elements of bell pepper. It is made entirely from one variety, and its oak is subtle and supportive.
Wine: Doren 2015 Doren Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)

Review: A woody and herbal nose follows through to the structured, rich palate, along with sage and cedar. Black cherry and currant define the flavors, while toasted oak lends support. The blend is 47% Cabernet Sauvignon, 33% Merlot, 10% Cabernet Franc, 6% Petit Verdot and 4% Malbec. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Kenzo Estate 2015 Rindo Estate Bottled Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From vines planted in 1974, this vine-designate is spicy, savory and rocky in mineral content, with a broadly lush palate that's succulent in texture. Immensely pleasurable and appealing, it has an exuberance of fruit and spice.
Wine: Lynmar 2016 Old Vines Quail Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is from an old-vines Wente clone, planted in 1977. You'll notice the texture first, layers of well-proportioned citrus, lemon zest, wet stone and hints of barrel toast. The length and detail are superb, and though drinking well already, this is a wine that will reward cellaring. Drink now through the 2020s.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 The High Wire Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Mt. Harlan, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Less than one-third of a ton per acre came off of this nearly 35-year-old vineyard from this drought-addled vintage, but what made it to bottle is quite amazing. Aromas of earthy thyme, sagebrush, wild black cherry and cocoa are layered and elegant. The palate is rich and thoroughly engaging in flavors of roasted tomato, mulberry and purple flower.
Wine: Calera 2015 Mills Vineyard Fortieth Anniversary Vintage Pinot Noir (Mt. Harlan)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a vineyard in Aptos just 4.5 miles from the ocean, this bottling begins with a bright fruity nose of alpine strawberry, red currants, dried thyme and lavender. The palate is fascinatingly floral, with rose petal, hibiscus and dried purple-flower flavors, wrapped around elegant cherry tones.
Wine: Lioco 2016 Saveria Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bradley Brown goes 100% whole cluster for this single-vineyard expression with stunning results. Aromas of sagebrush, pine needles, damp thyme and wet soil meet with tart raspberry on the distinctive nose. The palate's tangy red fruit is lifted by tea leaves, wild green sage and zesty acidity that vibrates the tongue.
Wine: Big Basin 2016 Lester Family Vineyards Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: This is a peppery, spicy wine that has a leathery, full-bodied feel. Succulent waves of blueberry are velvety smooth on the palate, offering an impressive marriage between richness and balance. The blend is mostly Merlot, with Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Malbec and Petit Verdot.
Wine: Kenzo Estate 2015 Murasaki Estate Bottled Proprietary Red (Napa Valley)

Review: Creamy stone-fruit and lemon-curd flavors provide an elegant richness to this coastal white. It is a bold, layered example of the variety that is well balanced by honed acidity.
Wine: Lynmar 2016 Susanna's Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Medium bodied and gritty on the palate, this has a richness of crème brûlée, the fruit a mix of quince and stone fruit. The acidity is emphasized in lingering layers of lime salt that remain vibrant on the finish.
Wine: Lynmar 2016 Old Wente Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From vines planted in 1973, this excellent bottling is superfresh with aromas of raspberry as well as loads of dark rock minerality, from crushed slate and wet clay to smashed soapstone. That earthy minerality shows on the sip as well, alongside sagebrush, thyme, peppercorns and intense boysenberry flavors.
Wine: Scar of the Sea 2016 Block Q Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: From the great site in Rutherford, this wine is dusty and weighty in blue fruit, leather and polished grippy tannin. With a touch of that grip on the texture, it shows as complex and robustly ripe and full bodied, offering an explosive concentration of up-front succulence and savory underbelly.
Wine: Boich 2016 Beckstoffer Vineyard Georges III Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: Floral in rose petal, lavender and savory spice, this tastes of rock and grit and tangy acidity. Offering substantial complexity from an unlikely site for the variety, high above the town of St. Helena, this is a beautifully made, delicate wine that shows structure and unending grace.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 La Perla Vineyard Pinot Noir (Spring Mountain District)

Review: A 100% varietal wine from the mountain appellation, this offers aromas of violet and cedar before delving into powerful flavors of cherry, blueberry and graham cracker. Well-developed tannins support the frame, retaining plenty of acidity and underlying succulence. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Davies 2015 Red Cap Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Review: Always one of the most reliable and well-priced Central Coast wines of any variety, this vintage's county-wide blend is fantastic, showing aromas of elderberry, lilac, wet slate, crushed gravel and uncracked peppercorns. It's rich and full of peppery spice on the palate, yet balanced by delicate black-plum and jasmine flavors.
Wine: Jaffurs 2016 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This best barrel blend from the winery's estate vineyard offers rustic red cherry, leather, game and mulling spice aromas on the dynamic nose. The lightly bodied but acid-driven palate shows sandalwood and hickory-smoked cherry flavors, proving extremely flavorful on a delicate frame.
Wine: Kynsi 2015 Precious Stone Corral Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This arresting wine slightly edged out two other single-vineyard offerings from this producer. Charming, snappy and also nicely concentrated, this medium-bodied wine offers a broad array of enticing aromas, vivid fruit flavors and great balance. It smells like red and black fruits with a touch of rhubarb, tastes fresh and fruity but also nuanced with tea and herb elements. It stays just on the lean side of the ripeness scale.
Wine: Pennyroyal Farm 2015 Eye of the Needle Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Macerated red plum is lifted by clove, allspice and an intriguing marzipan touch on the nose of this wine from a vineyard planted in 2006. The Christmas spice and gingerbread aromas are integrated into the plum and cherry backdrop.
Wine: Tantara 2016 Tondre Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: This outstanding wine compares well to cool-climate Syrahs, especially its aromas of French oak, new leather and turned earth. It has a deep, dark color, complex aromas, intense blackberry and coffee-bean flavors and a full but not overbearing body. The firm tannins provide good grip without drying. Best after 2021.
Wine: Boatique 2016 Petite Sirah (Red Hills)

Review: This is an intriguing and excitingly exotic red, delicately layered and balanced in freshness. It opens in crisp blueberry and orange-zest characteristics seasoned in baking spice and cardamom, finishing with as much elegance as it begins.
Wine: Flowers 2016 Sea View Ridge Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A jasmine aroma lifts from the glass as white peach lingers in the background. Sourced from the well-known Bacigalupi Vineyard, the palate is well textured and sizzling in lemon zest acidity.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2016 Bacigalupi Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Yorkville Highlands, North Coast, California, US
Review: This wine is raucous and raw-boned, exuding a powerful black-pepper aroma and a mouthcoating palate of beef, pepper, singed rosemary and blackberry. Owing some of its wild character to the use of 50% whole-cluster fermentation, the wine is medium to full in body, quite tannic and bone dry. It's not for the faint of heart, but the adventurous will love it.
Wine: Halcón 2016 Tierra Petite Sirah (Yorkville Highlands)

Review: This is a juicy, spicy and well-developed appellation wine—a testament to good winemaking and fruit. Cardamom, dark cherry, pomegranate and tannin combine well and find contrast and complement within a balanced light-bodied style.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: Structured in plenty of firm juicy acidity, this wine impresses from the get-go, offering softly layered elements of anise, pear and fig. Creamy and lush on the midpalate, it lingers in ginger and lemongrass exoticism, leaving a memorable impression.
Wine: Pellet Estate 2015 Sun Chase Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Review: This is a well-integrated wine from the warmer appellation, the oak and tannin relatively tamed within a rich framework of baked plum, cherry and exuberant acidity. The flavors are robustly concentrated and widely appealing.
Wine: Raymond 2015 District Collection Cabernet Sauvignon (Calistoga)

Review: Concentrated aromas of mulberry, exotic red cherry, crushed rose petals, crushed slate, tarragon and sandalwood make for a stunning entry to this always epic bottling by Jim Clendenen. Clean flavors of raspberry and red currant are lifted by dried herbs and tea spice on the palate, which is drinking great but will also age for eons. Drink now–2035.
Wine: Au Bon Climat 2015 Isabelle Pinot Noir (California)

Review: From another great site farmed by the famous Beckstoffer, this is grainy, textured and robustly ripe. Powerfully built to age and impress, it offers a wealth of lush, layered blue fruit and black licorice, as well as impressive structure. Enjoy 2026–2031.
Wine: Boich 2016 Beckstoffer Missouri Hopper Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A bright floral fragrance of rose rises seamlessly on the nose of this wine, as a full-bodied concentration of black raspberry develops on the palate. Asian spice, forest floor and black tea underline its varietal power and exoticism.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 Wohler Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Gamy aromas of lamb roast, rosemary, lavender and white pepper create an excellent cool-climate expression on this bottling by Chris Kiranbay. The palate is overloaded with green peppercorns, thyme and immense herbal and peppery spices deep into the finish.
Wine: Saint K 2016 Days Gone By Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Review: This is a powerfully perfumed red, inviting in lavender and rose petal, with a lasting impression of cardamom spice. It feels dense and rich within a context of balanced acidity and stemmy earthiness that lingers long on the finish.
Wine: Small Vines 2016 MK Vineyard Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark in the glass, this Syrah aged entirely in clay amphora is fascinating, starting with aromas of roasted lamb and crushed peppercorns. Firm, mouthcoating tannins frame the extremely intense and rich palate, which carries dark fruit and wet-clay flavors. Drink 2019–2030.
Wine: Zaca Mesa 2015 Amphora Estate Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Review: Dusty rock and mineral characterize this wine throughout its full-bodied concentration of ripe plum and black cherry. Cedar, graphite and oak provide context and additional complexity, rounding out on a finish of dried herb, clove and black pepper.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2015 Beckstoffer Georges III Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Review: This expertly blends 87% Cabernet Franc with 13% Merlot. The combination is unbeatable, characterized by graphite, cedar and a touch of reduction. Leathery texture that softens on the midpalate is robustly layered in blueberry and cinnamon.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2016 Gustaf Cabernet Franc-Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Intensely dark in the glass, this blend of 50% Cabernet Franc and 50% Merlot offers aromas of black currant, black cherry and mocha. A crushed-slate flavor makes for impressive minerality on the palate, where a baked-boysenberry flavor is framed by firm tannins yet a soft, mouthcoating texture.
Wine: Daou 2016 Seventeen Forty Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This is a “wow” wine: brawny, broad and juicy in black fruit. Blended with 5% Merlot and 4% Malbec, the grapes from the coolish appellation, it offers robust oak and tannin within savory notes of cedar, tobacco and toast. This is one worth cellaring; enjoy 2024–2029.
Wine: Darioush 2014 Darius II Cabernet Sauvignon (Mount Veeder)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral and spicy in ginger bread and a richness of crème brûlée, this is a big bold wine in style and approach. Fully realized flavors of baked pear give it additional power and concentration, as a lingering freshness of lemon zest sizzles on the finish.
Wine: Entrepreneur 2014 Bacigalupi Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Review: This offers acid-driven, crunchy red fruit that intertwines with rose petal and orange zest. Tightly wound tannins support an earthy core of forest, tobacco and tea, which complement the subtle fruit. It is light bodied and delicately ripe.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2016 Fort Ross Vineyard Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: This stunning sweet Riesling is sourced from the winery's Josef Vineyard. A concentrated nose of dried apricot, mango and honey carries a delicate sheen of polished wood. This is incredibly luscious and concentrated on the palate, persistent in juicy stone fruit and tropical flavors that are honed by laser-focused acidity. It's a powerful offering that lingers for days on the tongue and is sure to develop well with time in the bottle. Drink now–2028.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2016 Single Select Estate Bottled and Grown Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Review: Deep aromas of baked black currant, grilled beef and wild sagebrush make for a very compelling nose on this cool-climate expression of Syrah. Roasted meat and blackberry-paste flavors combine with rosemary, black pepper and pickling herbs on the palate, which is delicious and savory.
Wine: Odonata 2016 Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: Winemaker Geneviève Janssens blends 85% Cabernet Sauvignon from Hendry Ranch with 15% from Detert East Vineyard along the Oakville bench to produce this lovely, memorable and complex wine. Leathery and savory in black pepper, black currant and licorice, it features soft, plush tannins and beautiful aromas of violet that linger throughout.
Wine: Portfolio 2014 Limited Edition Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Tasty, toasty and refined, this mixes tree fruits and tropical fruit highlights with lush seams of caramel and maple syrup. It was fermented in 45% new French oak and put through full malolactic. Enjoy this delightful wine now through the mid-2020s.
Wine: Archery Summit 2016 Summit Vineyard Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)

Review: Brawny in supple baked black fruit, this wine is largely concentrated and robust in dense, secondary waves of mocha, black licorice and vanilla. Complex elements of dried herb and sage nip at the palate with ease, complementing the undeniable richness.
Wine: Jayson 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted game, turned earth and sagebrush aromas meet with rustic cherry on the nose of this bottling. There's an amazing array of flavors on the palate, from blistered tomato and pinched thyme to marjoram, tangy red plum skins and peppery spices.
Wine: Kynsi 2015 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: This wine was barrel fermented in 20% new French oak. It's racy, inviting and aromatic, with sharp flavors of lemon, gooseberry, lime and cantaloupe. Tart and stylish, it's built for aging, though immediately enjoyable. Drink now–2028.
Wine: Lavinea 2016 Lazy River Vineyard Chardonnay (Yamhill-Carlton)

Review: This is a powerfully built, age-worthy wine, robustly concentrated and dense in elements of tobacco, gunpowder, turned earth and leather. Sizable tannins give it additional weight and breadth, as well as structure: a sign of the vintage as well as site. Best 2025–2030.
Wine: M by Michael Mondavi 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Review: Gorgeous floral aromas and a rich, dense palate of saturated black fruits give power and breadth to this full-bodied and firmly textured wine. Aromas of violet, cinnamon and sandalwood make way for very ripe black-cherry and blueberry flavors underlain with firm but very fine-grained tannins.
Wine: Mirror 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Review: This wine has a bright entry of dark and red cherry and a nice grip of structure. Powerful, it provides a silky-smooth texture that's integrated with the tannins and oak, with complex accents of clove, leather and black pepper along the way.
Wine: Robert John 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Review: Brawny, dense and concentrated in cassis, this is made from 54% Merlot, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 1% Petit Verdot. The Merlot shows well in its soft layers of red cherry and plum, with the Cab accentuating a backbone of graphite, toasted oak and clove. This has years to go; best 2025–2030.
Wine: Round Pond 2015 Proprietary Left Bank Red (Rutherford)

Review: Winemaker Jeff Ames marks his first vintage with this producer, crafting an exceptional, age-worthy wine. The tightly structured palate is youthful, coiling in flavors of black raspberry, cherry pie and supportive oak. Let this one settle a bit; enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Tierra Roja 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Review: Beautifully floral and inviting, this wine has a nice weight to it and a balanced approach to ripeness and acidity. Peach, lemon and wet stone carry through a midpalate of silky smoothness and peppery finish. This is an impressive version of the variety.
Wine: Anaba 2017 Landa Vineyard Viognier (Sonoma Valley)

Review: This offers tremendous aromas of coffee and toffee, so inviting in their warmth and richness. A dusty leathery palate follows, structured in ageable firm tannin and robust flavors of black plum. This is worth cellaring; best 2026–2031.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2016 Aurum Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Macerated cherry aromas meet with dried sage and freshly dug earth on the nose of this bottling. Aromatic herbs and dried mint flavors meet with a red-fruit backbone on the intriguing palate.
Wine: Black Ridge 2014 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: From a high-elevation vineyard above Petaluma, this wine has a great depth of floral and mineral aromatics that invite one in immediately. Meyer lemon, crisp green apple and wet stone accentuate its acid-driven nature that's broadly quenching and complex.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 Fault Line Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This atypical blend of Pinot Noir and Grenache is always a fun release for this winery, and the pairing works very well. Aromas of bay leaf, thyme, red currant and rosewater lead into a palate loaded with star anise, mace and dried red-cherry flavors. The structure is light but the floral freshness is lovely.
Wine: Kynsi 2015 Nocturnum Red (Edna Valley)

Review: Briny lemon and tangerine lift a creamy lush personality buoyant in complementary and well-integrated acidity. This wine offers a wealth of succulence and complexity, trafficking in bold flavors and structure.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 The Key Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Review: This is a heck of a deal for the quality: an appellation wine with juicy intensity and a rich layering of red and blue fruit. With plenty of tannic power beneath its integrated texture are secondary notes of forest, clove and black tea that complement the fruit beautifully.
Wine: Patz & Hall 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Elegant black cherry, star anise and mace make for a fresh but spicy nose on this single-vineyard expression in a new Zinfandel project by the Kathryn Hall wine family. Luscious flavors of blackberry sorbet are wrapped in an earthy structure, with layers of rosemary and roasted beef arising through the sip. The acid-washed finished is laced with pepper.
Wine: Baca 2016 Double Dutch Dusi Vineyard Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling, using grapes grown at 1,400-feet in elevation and made with 31% whole cluster, shows candied blackberry, cola and fennel-frond aromas on the nose. It's tightly woven on the palate, where pinpoint tannins and bright acid deliver elderberry paste and white-sage flavors.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Rattlesnake Rock Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Lush and oaky despite its light-bodied delicacy of restrained ripeness, this wine has floral undertones that present as mineral and earth. It has a balanced bite of green apple and lemon curd and tons of structure that should support it over time.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 Manchester Ridge Vineyard Chardonnay (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Perfectly baked apple aromas meet with crisp white flowers and fresh kumquat on the nose of this bottling by a winery based in Malibu. Bright lemon and honeysuckle flavors make for a mouthwatering palate, rounded by savory touches of sandalwood and framed with tense structure.
Wine: Dolin 2015 Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black currant, charred berries and a hint of diesel show on the nose of this dark and intense bottling from Ballard Canyon. The dark-fruit flavors continue on the sip, but are lifted by rosemary, bay leaf and chalky tannins.
Wine: Jaffurs 2015 Larner Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: If cool-climate Petite Sirah ever becomes a trend, this bottling will lead the pack. Aromas of cracked pepper, tar and hearty black plum lead into a palate where boysenberry is lifted by white pepper, thyme and rosemary. It's zesty and fascinating.
Wine: Jaffurs 2016 Thompson Vineyard Petite Sirah (Santa Barbara County)

Review: This is a richly built wine, with flavors of juicy black cherry and baking spice. Citrus-driven acidity offers length to the full-bodied palate.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: Rusty cherries, sagebrush and a touch of game make for a rich but rustic entry to this clonal study by Sabrine Rodems. Smoke, red cherry and star anise make for a spicy and zesty sip, lifted by buoyant acidity.
Wine: Wrath 2016 Pommard 4/777 Pinot Noir (Monterey)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A round Bing cherry aroma combines with vanilla and nutmeg on the ripe, accessible nose. It's delicious on the palate, with broad red-fruit flavors, a tight structure and just enough astringency to keep it in balance.
Wine: Zaca Mesa 2016 Homage Collection Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: This rich and fruity wine is irresistible in its flavors of apple, orange, tangerine and apricot. It's juicy and plump, fresh and full bodied, with a touch of toast from 30% new French oak fermentation.
Wine: Archery Summit 2016 Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light in the glass, this elegant bottling by Jim Clendenen shows spicy aromas of mace, crushed sage and eucalyptus, set against tangy cranberry and hibiscus aromas. It's a sprightly wine on the palate, with thyme, bay leaf and rusty cranberry flavors. Drink now through 2035.
Wine: Au Bon Climat 2015 Knox Alexander Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Grown at about 2,200 feet above the Salinas Valley with views of the Monterey Bay, this bottling, which saw 88% whole-cluster fermentation, shows crushed hibiscus, spicy cinnamon, anise and red plum on the pungent nose. Crisp pomegranate and raspberry flavors meet with sumac and aromatic mints on the palate.
Wine: Big Basin 2016 Coastview Vineyard Pinot Noir (Monterey County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine is complex, concentrated and deep, like an old-vine wine should be. It shows whiffs of dried earth, sage and black pepper in the aroma and hearty flavors that range from savory herbs to potent blackberry and clove. It is full bodied, dry, firmly tannic and has a long lingering finish.
Wine: Fiddletown Cellars 2016 Old Vine Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black plum, turned loam, spice cake and tar aromas show on the nose of this blend of 62% Syrah, 34% Grenache and 4% Mourvèdre. It's rich and thick on the palate, with strong black-currant and licorice flavors that are simultaneously delivered with power and finesse.
Wine: Justin 2015 Trilateral Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Keeler is doing some interesting experimentation with fermentation methods, and here they deliver a stunning amphora-fermented, off-dry Riesling. The wine offers a fine mix of apricot, peach and nectarine tones that display a sweet and sour tension. It finishes with a lick of butterscotch.
Wine: Keeler 2017 Terracotta Amphorae Riesling (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light in the glass, this wine from a vineyard off of Santa Rosa Road offers aromas of muddled cherry and crushed thyme in a rustic, herbaceous style. The palate is refreshing and layered with oregano, marjoram and peppercorn, set against a raspberry backdrop.
Wine: Ken Brown 2015 Rancho La Vina Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: This is a bright, complex and succulent single-vineyard designate that is also textured and beguilingly delicate. Cherry, blueberry and plum flavors wrap around Asian five spice and savory cardamom elements that season the light lovely body.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Sun Chase Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: A mountain-grown wine blended with 10% Petit Verdot, this impresses in its ability to offer power and elegance in equal measure. Cinnamon, baked plum and dark cherry ride along a soft, structured and age-worthy wine, which shows a touch of reduction, espresso bean and dusty rock minerality.
Wine: La Jota Vineyard 2015 Merlot (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: An intense mix of rosemary, lavender, asphalt and elderberry jam makes for an attention-grabbing entry into this bottling from the Los Alamos Valley. The savory palate is reminiscent of beef roasted in an herb-laced plum sauce, with cracked black pepper and grated coffee beans atop.
Wine: Margerum 2015 Black Oak Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Review: Intense and concentrated aromas of black raspberry and alpine strawberry prove dark and rich but not overripe. The palate is framed by warm oak flavors that bind the rich strawberry and plum elements, which are offset by an orange-rind tang.
Wine: Odonata 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Pure focused fruit aromas make this wine instantly appealing and it only gets better on the palate where hints of black tea and sour cherry meet a gorgeous and just-ripe black-cherry core. Vibrant acidity and light tannins give the wine a good nervy mouthfeel while the medium body contains layers of fruits and spices that continue flowing on the finish.
Wine: Pennyroyal Farm 2015 Jean Sheep Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Floral aromas and concentrated black-cherry flavors mark this medium- to full-bodied wine as something distinctive. It smells of enticing rose petal and light lilac, tastes vivid and fruity but not overripe. Firm tannins and lively acidity lift the texture and while the good concentration leads to a lingering finish.
Wine: Pennyroyal Farm 2015 Monty In Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Arroyo Grande Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling relies heavily on dry-farmed bush vines planted in 1880, and their unique impact is on full display. Tightly wound blackberry aromas combine with tobacco leaf, loamy soil and dried meat on the nose. Elderflower and elderberry flavors show on the sip, which is firm with chalky tannins, bright with acid and elegantly layered. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Saucelito Canyon 2015 Estate Zinfandel (Arroyo Grande Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe aromas of Anjou pear and apple are leveled by clean lines of white rock minerality and wet river stones on the nose of this block-designated bottling. Tangy pear and lime flavors are fresh and zesty, with more wet rock touches in the background.
Wine: Scar of the Sea 2016 Mount Eden Clone Block 11 Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: An exciting focus helps this wine stand out. It is full bodied, dry and well-concentrated, offering fresh black-cherry and cedar aromas, deep fruit flavors accented by light smoky peppery spices and a nicely firm texture that is moderately tannic. The complexity is partly due to 15% Petite Sirah in the blend, and aging in 35% new American and French oak barrels.
Wine: Three 2016 Evangelho Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Review: Floral in a heady mix of cherry blossom and lavender, this light-styled red is sanguine in red currant and cassis. Firm tannins provide support without distraction, the oak equally integrated and subtle. Robust and ripe on the midpalate, the wine has a graceful finish.
Wine: Ackerman 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Review: This is intensely flavored in apricot and mango, the aromatics floral and beautiful in jasmine. Fleshy and broad, it lingers in oak and elements of wild vanilla and baking spice.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2015 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very few producers make a good domestic Marsanne, and Alta Colina is now near the top of that list. Elegant aromas of white-fleshed fruit and lime rinds meet with honey dust on the nose. The palate is very tense with chalky texture and a lemony edge giving nuance to the broad yellow-apple, chamomile and honey-butter flavors.
Wine: Alta Colina 2016 Claudia Cuvée Marsanne (Adelaida District)

Review: Juicy, dusty and mineral-driven, this wine is balanced and fresh on the palate—a study in contrasts between savory and the succulence of plum, dark cherry and just a touch of vanilla. Lush and fleshy, it retains plenty of acidity throughout.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 Cougar Rock Vineyard Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Cienega Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The history of this remote property is fascinating, and more will come to love its story thanks to excellent wines such as this. Aromas of black cherry, loamy soils and tarragon lead into a palate redolent with sagebrush, marjoram and minty forest floor flavors. Wild strawberry and red currant touches provide fruity depth.
Wine: Eden Rift 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Cienega Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Brawny, juicy and lushly layered, this wine impresses in its full-bodied concentration of strawberry jam and biscuit flavors, with soft, approachable tannins. Black tea and a twist of clove give it an understated warmth and spicy persistence.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2016 Hallberg Vineyard-Dijon Clones Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rose petals, crushed rocks, rounded red plum and nutmeg show strongly on the compelling nose of this bottling. It's very level on the palate, with tight tannins carrying bright fruit, rosewater and purple-flower flavors. With time, there will be smoother texture and more baking-spice flavors. Drink 2021–2035.
Wine: Giornata 2015 Luna Matta Vineyard Nebbiolo (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied boysenberry, white pepper and thyme-crusted roast aromas show on the nose of this bottling from a seminal vineyard in the Los Alamos area. Tightly woven on the palate, the wine is very expressive and floral, with flavors of violet, elderflower and black-plum skins.
Wine: Jaffurs 2015 Thompson Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lavish aromas of dried raspberry, black sage, hibiscus and boysenberry make for a generous entry to this bottling from a vineyard in the heart of the Sta. Rita Hills. The palate shows more herbal touches, including thyme, marjoram and tea leaves, giving depth to the boysenberry and white-pepper flavors.
Wine: Ken Brown 2015 Rita's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Briny sea salt and lemon open this wine in a bright, acid-driven way—a statement that follows through in an integrated meaty substance. A lingering flavor of just-ripe white peach adds to the complexity and delicious succulence.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Sun Chase Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Both concentrated and luxurious, this wine is a classic that offers a broad range of enticing aromas, plenty of delicious fruit in the middle and a lingering finish. Clove, cedar and cassis fill the aromas, while ripe blueberry and black cherry flood the palate. A great balance of a velvety texture and soft tannins holds it all together.
Wine: Lava Cap 2016 Estate Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (El Dorado)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is the winery's entry-level Pinot Noir, and it's a screaming deal. Aromas of black raspberry, hibiscus and purple flowers make for an elegant and pretty nose that's both high toned and approachable. Alpine strawberry and rose-petal flavors ride a crushed rock minerality and taut texture of fine tannins and bright acidity.
Wine: Scar of the Sea 2016 Seven Leagues Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: From the wilds of the appellation and blended with 16% Merlot and 9% Cabernet Franc, this wine is dense, layered and soft—a robust expression of chocolate, caramel and juicy blackberry. The oak is well integrated and supportive of polished powerful tannins.
Wine: Sill Family 2015 Très Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This deep and concentrated wine seems to have a story to tell. Hints of rosemary and clove accent dark black-cherry and raspberry flavors that layer through the rich texture and seem to accelerate on the finish. It's an unusually expressive and complex Zinfandel that was aged in 37% new French and American barrels, and contains 14% Petite Sirah plus smaller amounts of Carignan and Alicante.
Wine: Three 2016 Bigelow Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Review: Loads of white pepper and caraway spice up the backdrop of black-plum paste on the awesome nose of this bottling. There is tons of zippy acidity on the palate, where snappy boysenberry and white-pepper spices deliver immense energy.
Wine: Zotovich 2016 Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Allan Hancock College's vineyard is in the city of Santa Maria, and much closer to the coast than most of the Santa Maria Valley appellation. That gives this Syrah extreme cool-climate character, from tar, peppercorn, roasted lamb and black-currant paste on the nose to a tense palate loaded with cracked pepper, rosemary and game. Fresh acidity provides a juicy quality too.
Wine: Allan Hancock 2016 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This dark and brooding wine has everything in spades. The color is reddish-black, the aromas are full of new leather, oak dust and black cherry, while the flavors are ripe, generous black cherry, blueberry and dark chocolate. The 40% new American barrels adds spicinesss. There is no lack of the grape variety's famous tannins, but they are fine grained and contribute to a velvety saturated mouthfeel.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2015 Estate Tempranillo (Amador County)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of Meyer lemon cream and crushed hazelnuts are deliciously inviting on the nose of this bottling from the winery's historic vineyard series. White peach, walnut, smoke and tangy grapefruit converge on the dynamic palate.
Wine: Au Bon Climat 2016 Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine tastes alive and fresh, showing an abundance of fruit flavors, fine concentration and very good balance. Strawberry and raspberry notes are supported by deeper blackberry flavors, moderate tannins and good acidity for a grippy mouthfeel.
Wine: Bella 2016 Lily Hill Estate Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From the Antle and Brosseau vineyards in the Chalone AVA, this 53% Mourvèdre, 30% Grenache and 17% Syrah blend offers rich caramel, chocolate, black-cherry and bay leaf aromas on the nose. There's a great display of herbs across the palate, giving depth to the rich black-plum backdrop, framed by rounded acidity and tannic tension.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Gabilan Mountains G-S-M (Monterey County)

Review: This immensely concentrated and densely layered wine is impressive for its deep dark color, intense blackberry and dark-chocolate aromas, saturated blueberry flavors and a thick wrapping of fine-grained tannins. Fans of big rich wines will love it now, with a roasted or grilled chunk of meat, and it will age well. Best after 2023.
Wine: Binz 2015 Oleta Vineyard Petite Sirah (Fiddletown)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine is made from some of the smallest, densest berries on the property's northern end, a warm, intense place for grapes. Floral on the nose, it presents chalky tannin, ash and crushed rock-like minerality around a core of red and black cherry as well as plum. It offers substantial concentration and robust richness.
Wine: Chimney Rock 2015 Clone 4 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Review: From the exciting appellation that is Coombsville, this wine starts with beautiful aromas of violet and clove before opening up on the palate to a generous array of blackberry, plum and black pepper. Full bodied, it shows elegance and a sense of balance that holds up through a lengthy finish.
Wine: Faust 2015 The Pact Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The historic vineyard shows well in this impressive wine, which opens in an earthy mix of black peppercorn and black tea. Soft and seductive on the palate, it lingers in citrus-laden acidity that lifts up flavors of cranberry, strawberry and nutmeg.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2016 Rochioli Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: Black-raspberry, forest floor, wet tobacco and peppercorn aromas show on the layered and minty nose of this bottling. The fresh palate is taut and tart with bright red fruits that benefit from complex touches of thyme, bay leaf and green peppercorn.
Wine: Jaffurs 2015 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of dried cranberry, hibiscus, rooibos tea, mace and grated ginger combine on the nose of this appellation blend. Intense flavors of elderflower and violet make for an elegantly vibrant palate, which is framed by intense black-raspberry fruit.
Wine: Sanford 2016 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: A 100% varietal wine, this impresses mightily in its offering of blueberry-cobbler flavor and graham cracker. Dark chocolate and white pepper contrast easily within bright polished tannins and a lingering finish of leather and graphite.
Wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2015 Malbec (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Lavish oak spices soften and complement the concentrated fruit flavors of this full-bodied, thickly textured wine. It shows hints of wood smoke and baking spices in the aroma and cinnamon and cardamom notes on the palate as a rich layer of fine-grained tannins coats the tongue. It's delicious and stylish.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2015 Karmere Vineyards Petite Sirah (Amador County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This top-tier Sauvignon Blanc is crisp, clear, clean and tangy, with just enough grass and gooseberry characters that are balanced by grapefruit. This should drink well over the next five years, into the mid-2020s.
Wine: Andrew Rich 2017 Croft Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Willamette Valley)

Review: This wine is still quite young, which makes it very energetic if not yet fully evolved. Aromas of crushed hibiscus, elderberry and smoked meat lead into a palate of plum, berry, game and dried sage. It's both rich and zesty at once.
Wine: Barden 2017 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Too bad California doesn't make more Semillons like this. While technically light-bodied, this wine tastes nutty and feels smooth, bringing a lot of richness to the palate along with buttery earthy almond-like flavors. It has a touch of astringency and acidity to counterpoint its weight and support the complex and evolved character of the flavors.
Wine: Bee Hunter 2015 Semillon (Yorkville Highlands)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Coming from a mountain vineyard nearly 2,300 feet above the eastern Salinas Valley, this blend of 44% Cabernet Sauvignon, 38% Merlot, 8% Cabernet Franc, 6% Malbec and 4% Petit Verdot offers a taste of a unique terroir. Aromas of red cherry, oregano and cigar box lead into a complex palate of tangy black-plum skin and dried herbs, all framed by strong acid and a light but taut structure.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Altitude 2292 Red (Monterey County)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: An enveloping nose of apple, pineapple, tangerine and jasmine mixes with an earthy base note. The medium-bodied palate is textural and waxy in feel, with hi-def flavors of apple skin, white blossoms and orange that are graced by a tangy wet-slate note.
Wine: Empire Estate 2017 Dry Reserve Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: This is an exceptionally well-made wine at the price point: floral and appealing in quiet waves of citrus, baked pear and nutmeg. Integrated oak gives it power and strength within an edge of mineral-laden acidity.
Wine: La Crema 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling, which originates from the Corralitos area, is quite showy on the nose, with black-cherry, raspberry sorbet, vanilla and caramel aromas all prominent. It dries up a bit on the sip, where a chalky texture is wrapped around blackberry, star anise and nutmeg flavors.
Wine: Left Bend 2015 Gali Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz County)

Review: A-pure black-cherry character practically leaps out of the glass as this medium-bodied wine offers enticing aromas, satisfying fruit flavors and a firm lip-smacking texture. Nuances of forest floor and black tea join with abundant cherries to give complexity and interest.
Wine: Pennyroyal Farm 2016 Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Review: This is a simply gorgeous bottle that's loaded with fresh and palate-pleasing flavors of cut pear. Lively acidity with a mix of citrus brings extra life and length, and this will show best if decanted for an hour or two prior to drinking.
Wine: Portlandia 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Review: Five years in, and this wine is still very much alive. Concentrated red-currant and black-cherry aromas meet with vanilla, gingerbread and crushed violet on the lavish nose. The palate is also lush, proving soft in structure with full-bodied flavors of black cherry, milk chocolate, red flowers and baking spice.
Wine: Westerly 2013 Red (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This 50% Syrah and 50% Grenache shows many cool-climate hallmarks that come from this region, with blackberry, purple flower and a hint of charcoal on the nose. The layers are slowly revealed on the palate, with dark strawberry and plum skipping into lavish tones of baking spice. Acid drives deep into the finish.
Wine: Zotovich 2016 Heritage Red (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: This blends 66% Cabernet Sauvignon with 28% Cabernet Franc, 4% Merlot and 2% Petit Verdot. Together, they combine for a soft rounded palate of smoky cherry, currant, clove and cinnamon. A light grip of tannin gives it additional power and statement, with a finish of black pepper. Enjoy 2026–2031.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2016 Eloge Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From Jim Clendenen's historic vineyard collection of wines, this bottling (from the vineyard that surrounds his winery) is light in the glass with aromas of red cherry, bay leaf, juniper and vanilla. The herbal attack is powerful on the palate, where oregano, sage and chamomile lift up the cranberry and pomegranate fruit.
Wine: Au Bon Climat 2015 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rusty and gamy aromas of blood meet with light cranberry and charred wood on the nose of this bottling by Jim Clendenen and team. The body is light yet carries immense waves of flavors, including sarsaparilla, pomegranate and smoke.
Wine: Au Bon Climat 2015 La Bauge Au-dessus Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded cherry aromas are lifted by light licorice spice and sweet herbs on the nose of this clonal study. The lightweight mouthfeel is tense with pinpoint tannins, offering flavors of black raspberry, orange rind and spicy fruit punch.
Wine: Bargetto 2017 Pommard Clone Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This reserve blend of 55% Grenache, 25% Syrah, 16% Mourvèdre and 4% Cinsaut takes a good amount of patience to open, but is quite compelling when it does. Candied cherry and hibiscus aromas meet with rusty sanguine aromas on the nose, while the palate combines red fruit with raw meat and feral flavors. A baking-spice warmth evolves with time.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2013 Le Cigare Volant Reserve Red (Central Coast)

Review: This blends grapes from three tremendous sites: Chenoweth Ranch, Treehouse and Bootlegger's Hill, all sites farmed by Charlie Chenoweth himself. It melds and marries aspects of fruit and spice effortlessly around a tightly packed bit of power and ongoing freshness, with a perspective of Asian spice and black cherry.
Wine: Chenoweth 2015 Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a thick, richly layered red from the producer's site—one of the cooler sides of the vineyard. Lush on the palate, it has tender elements of black currant, smoked meat, black pepper, licorice and lavender, a complex array of elements that shows room for further evolution. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Chimney Rock 2015 Tomahawk Vineyard Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine is bold and straightforward, with just a little oak spiciness and a generous supply of black-fruit flavors and fine-grained tannins. It has a sense of layering and creaminess that keeps it drinkable despite the tannic grip. Best after 2023.
Wine: Concannon 2016 Captain Joe's Reserve Petite Sirah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Creamy and lushly full bodied, this wine is complemented by a gritty texture of mineral and crushed rock, the whole integrated and well structured. Bold ripe flavors of pear are met by baking spice and toasted oak that linger with abandon on the finish.
Wine: Entrepreneur 2016 Bacigalupi Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine from a Zin specialist has soul and spices, combining ripe and rich berry flavors with attractive hints of sage and black pepper. It is full bodied, smooth and lush in texture and offers just a touch of tannin for good structure.
Wine: Fiddletown Cellars 2015 Indian Creek Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is the brand new project from Alex Gambal and Peter Work of Ampelos Cellars in the Sta. Rita Hills, where Gambal is hoping to replicate his Burgundian style. This wine's rounded aromas of white peach, sea salt caramel and nectarine syrup lead into an energetic palate that's sharply citrus at first before the chalky minerality takes hold.
Wine: Gambal + Work 2016 Francesca Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an intensely built, dense red that is sultry and full bodied yet totally in balance. Tangy dark cherry, pomegranate and black tea are accented by rose petal and orange zest, finishing on a lush expanse of vanilla.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2016 Toboni Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: This is a hearty, acid-driven white, with a white peach flavor and a lush, creamy palate. Hints of jasmine and apple blossom meld with a touch of lemon zest on the lingering finish.
Wine: Kenzo Estate 2017 Asatsuyu Estate Bottled Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fresh and deep, this offers ripe fruit flavors of apple, Asian pear and white melon. It was fermented in barrel with native yeast and 20% new oak. The structure, as with all Lavinea wines, is perfectly balanced for optimal tension and texture.
Wine: Lavinea 2016 Elton Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling by Ian Brand always packs bang for the buck, but he really nailed it in the 2017 vintage. Clean and delicate aromas of Asian pear, lemon rind and edgy chalk lead into a racy, crisp and tightly wound palate. Flavors of grapefruit, nectarine, blanched almond and sea salt are delicious.
Wine: Le P'tit Paysan 2017 Jacks Hill Chardonnay (Monterey County)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
