Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This wine offers a deft mix of rose petal, baby powder and lychee aromas. There's plenty of spice, and, as it's bone dry, it matches well with peppery noodle dishes.
Wine: Foris 2017 Dry Gewürztraminer (Rogue Valley)

Review: It would behoove this talented producer of Alsatian-style white wines to adopt the universal Riesling scale on the back label, in order to emphasize the crisp, food-friendly style here. Though not bone dry—there's a light hint of residual sugar—it's dry enough to work well with many foods. Lemon tea, orange rind and pink grapefruit flavors abound, backed by clean, cutting acidity.
Wine: Foris 2017 Riesling (Rogue Valley)

Review: This is a big bottle made to mark the winery's 25th anniversary. Integrated, rich and well-structured, it merits its purpose, offering dusty mineral notes around a softness of oak, clove, cedar and chocolate toffee.
Wine: Frank Family 2015 Owner's Red (Rutherford)

Review: This is a brawny and broad reserve-level wine that's grippy and dusty in tannins. Powerful red fruit matches the rich concentration, the acidity textured and well-integrated to offer complementary brightness in contrast to the big flavor.
Wine: Kokomo 2015 Ruth's Vineyard Winemaker's Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Review: This wine is lighthearted and approachable yet structured, with earthy elements of turned earth and dried herb. The palate is grippy in tannin and dark in blackberry and chocolate flavors.
Wine: Louis M. Martini 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)

Review: This is made from 80% Pinot Noir, the remainder Chardonnay. It offers inviting aromas of strawberry and orange around a tightly structured layering of flavor and bright acidity.
Wine: Mumm Napa NV Brut Rosé Sparkling (Napa County)

Review: From a Conn Valley vineyard estate and 100% varietal, this wine is tightly wound and full bodied, reflective of the vintage and the warmer climes. It is intensely flavored and dense, grippy in leathery tannin and oak power, with a dusting of dried herb and graphite.
Wine: Neyers 2015 AME Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Review: Juicy with just a slight touch of reduction, this wine is thick and well-integrated—a small-production offering that reflects well on the appellation. Plum, black cherry and hints of black licorice toy with the nose and palate, finishing in balance and grace.
Wine: Paratus 2014 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Mount Veeder)

Review: This is a well-made version of the rare variety—oily and floral with a gritty underbelly of texture. Apple, rose water and lemon provide an exotic framework of balanced acidity and crispness.
Wine: Red Car 2015 Vivio Vineyard Roussanne (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: This is a ripe, forward dry Riesling that offers mango, apple and stone fruit on the nose. The palate is equally fruit-laden, yet well-balanced by honed acidity and delicate astringency. A light lemon curd tone lingers on the finish.
Wine: Red Tail Ridge 2017 Dry RTR Estate Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: This has both lush tannin and tangy acidity, the two complementing each other well along a full-bodied offering of strawberry, forest floor and black tea. Savory on the nose, it remains tart on the palate in a finish of rhubarb.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Green Label Sangiacomo Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: With 5% Merlot blended in, this beastly wine boasts bright tones of cassis and currant, with lingering accents of coconut and vanilla. Big, dense and concentrated, it has a ton of structure, grippy tannin and oak.
Wine: Roots Run Deep Winery 2014 The Valedictorian Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Smoked hazelnut and rich oak aromas are cut by whiffs of lemon rind, citrus spray, chalk and Asian pear on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate offers both sharp citrus and rounded apple flavors.
Wine: Sanford 2016 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A rugged blend of 50% Zinfandel, 35% Tempranillo and 15% Petite Sirah, this bottling by the Greenough family shows concentrated aromas of black plum and black currant alongside tobacco and leather on the nose. It's thick and ripe on the palate, but balanced enough, offering powerful black-fruit flavors wit pinches of sage and incense.
Wine: Saucelito Canyon 2015 Muchacho Red (San Luis Obispo County)

Review: This appellation wine is brawny in brambly red and black cherry, tight full-bodied robustness and ripeness. Toasted oak imparts a warmth and seasoning of vanilla cola.
Wine: Sojourn 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A rich and concentrated varietal wine, this is tannic and edgy, with robust layers of rhubarb, cherry cola and dark chocolate. Its oak imprint is strong and seasoned in vanilla.
Wine: Sonoma-Loeb 2016 Bateman Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: In the midst of a major transformation to new varieties, a biodynamic vineyard and innovative fermentations, Troon scores with this rich, toasty, barrel-fermented white wine. A ripe mix of fruits brings poached pear and banana to the front, with a lick of vanilla custard as the wine trails off. Delicious already, so drink up.
Wine: Troon 2017 Vermentino (Applegate Valley)

Review: Earthy cedar gives this wine a savory character that impresses, as well as a well-integrated core of chalky tannin, moderate oak and black-cherry ripeness. It provides substantial mouthfeel and approachability.
Wine: V. Sattui 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Refreshing aromas of lime, crushed stone, white peach and green apple skin carry to the light-bodied palate, where a brisk tonic tone keeps things pristine and crisp. This dry-style Riesling is well balanced by tangy acidity and a pleasantly astringent green-plum-skin finish.
Wine: Wagner 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Defined aromas of apple, white blossoms, lime and stone shine in this off-dry Riesling. The well-textured palate is succulent in feel, with a snappy orchard-fruit flavor that's backed by a waxy lemon note.
Wine: Wagner 2017 Select Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked strawberry and mulberry aromas are lifted by gingersnap elements on the nose of this bottling. Concentrated red-plum and licorice flavors show on the very extracted palate, which gains a slight tartness from the acidity.
Wine: Wrath 2016 Boekenoogen Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A stony nose of limestone and freshly zested citrus leads to a juicy palate of green melon and apple flavors. This dry Riesling offers well-concentrated orchard-fruit and citrus flavors that are held in check by a persistent line of acidity.
Wine: Anthony Road 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Bright, fresh and balanced, this is a fruity white with bold flavors of baked peach and apricot. A nutty undertone adds a touch of richness and texture.
Wine: Benessere 2017 Pinot Grigio (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from a 1979 planting, this crisp, steely wine seems to have been made entirely in stainless steel, to good effect. Stylish apple fruit is highlighted with hints of chervil and parsley, and a twist of lemon peel finishes it off.
Wine: Brooks 2017 Brooks Estate Vineyard Pinot Gris (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: A tangy plum aroma meets turned soil on the rustic and rugged nose of this appellation blend by the historic winery, now owned by Duckhorn. The turned earth component shows on the palate as well, with additional flavors of thyme, dried sage, plum and baked sour cherry.
Wine: Calera 2016 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Review: This is a thick, rich and unctuously varietal wine, smoky in oak and beautifully wrapped layers of grilled meat and game. A thicket of lavender and licorice gives it complexity and more to ponder.
Wine: Coursey Graves 2016 West Slope Syrah (Bennett Valley)

Review: This wine offers cool-climate characteristics of spice, turned earth and pencil. Its plummy fruit is largely structured around a robust body of power and weight. Aged in both French and American oak, it persists on the finish in a mix of black pepper and sage.
Wine: Crosby Roamann 2013 Merlot (Oak Knoll District)

Review: Up-front oak gives way to a brightness of Meyer lemon in this ultimately medium-bodied structured white. Briny salty mineral elements pique a lusher midpalate of pineapple, fig and nutmeg, contrasting well to offer memorable complexity.
Wine: Cuvaison 2016 Kite Tail Chardonnay (Carneros)

Review: Done in a ripe, rich and toasty style, this is quite tasty in a mainstream sort of way. It's full bodied and ready for immediate enjoyment. What's missing is the precision of place that could elevate it still further.
Wine: Elton 2016 Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: Floral in musque-like aromatics, this is a well-integrated and fruity white, crisply showing its stainless-steel fermentation. Apple, lime and peach play well with each other to offer bold, memorable flavors.
Wine: Girard 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: Sweet peach and apricot flavors are given a touch of richness from a jolt of vanilla. Medium bodied and fleshy, it finishes bright and fresh.
Wine: Herencia 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: Tea, forest floor and rose petal combine forcefully on the nose of this wine, before a torrent of thick, underlying cranberry and cassis take over. The savory complements the fruit well, finishing in a twist of burnt orange peel.
Wine: Iris 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Intensely textured and concentrated in fruit, this is marked by a depth of mango and pineapple with generous oak imparting toffee and caramel. It finds its balance midpalate with supportive acidity that lasts throughout a long finish.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Lorenzo Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Review: This wine has light aromas of figs and crushed stone, followed by a creamy mouthfeel and subtle flavors of almond and white pepper. A couple of years in the cellar will bring out more complexity. Best after 2020.
Wine: Lava Cap 2017 Viognier (El Dorado)

Review: Baked strawberry is enveloped by wraparound oak in this concentrated full-bodied wine. Exotic aromas of rose accompany the fruit as substantial tannins ride along and tighten the texture.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 Putnam Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: Blended with 11% Petit Verdot, then aged more than two years in 100% new French oak, this is built for power, exhibiting hugely tannic structure and vanilla oak. Black currant, cedar and dried herb dot the palate before a dense richness of chocolate comes to the fore.
Wine: Merus 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Review: Rounded aromas of dark strawberry, black pepper, smoke and vanilla show on the nose of this bottling by the Riboli family. It's smooth and very drinkable on the palate, with flavors of French toast, red plum and dark strawberry jelly.
Wine: Opaque 2013 Malbec (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Intense aromas of rich cherry, clove and smashed plum show on the nose of this bottling from a steep hilltop vineyard. The palate is very full and lavish with dark plum and strong baking-spice flavors.
Wine: Point & Line 2016 John Sebastiano Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: High-toned acidity supports bright fresh flavors of peach, apricot and green apple in this well-made lightly bodied white. Floral aromas of jasmine and apple blossom complement the fruit.
Wine: Quivira 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Review: Labelled in velvet, the thick dense texture of this wine is equally soft and richly built, with substantial tannin and oak on display. Bright red cherry and cassis are interwoven between the powerful ripeness.
Wine: Raymond 2015 Reserve Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe yellow apple and peach resound on the nose, with underscores of lemon and white blossoms. The medium-bodied palate is fleshy and round, broadened out by plenty of ripe fruit flavors yet balanced by well-honed, orange-laden acidity.
Wine: Red Tail Ridge 2016 Dry RTR Estate Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: This is an acid-driven, light-bodied wine that offers elements of black tea and forest floor. Amidst the savory tones are tasty flavors of cranberry, brambly cherry and orange zest.
Wine: Ron Rubin 2015 Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A watermelon aroma meets a sharp lime edge on the nose of this zesty wine. It's tightly woven on the palate, where a chalky mouthfeel and citrus-driven flavors make a good pairing.
Wine: Villa San Juliette 2017 Small Lot Selection Reserve Rosé (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a reduced, thick and richly intense wine from the mountain appellation. It is robust in black fruit and grippy tannin. The fruit takes on a baked quality that works within its context of savory tobacco, clove and black pepper.
Wine: Waypoint 2014 Tierra Buena Cabernet Sauvignon (Spring Mountain District)

Review: Hearty red-fruit and graham cracker richness mark this well-made wine, blended with 8% Cabernet Sauvignon. A generous tannin structure provides a framework for the ripe weight as the finish explores aspects of sweet tobacco.
Wine: Whitehall Lane 2015 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas start out light, with notes of blackberry, herb, sagebrush, olive, dried flower and cherry reduction. The palate is balled up in the middle, with the tannins seeming a bit clenched out of the gate, spreading out with a few days open. A warm finish caps it off. Give it a few years in the bottle or an extended decant.
Wine: Avennia 2016 Le Corbeau Discovery Vineyard Syrah (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Well-formed aromas of honeydew melon and white blossom meet a tangy, steel element on the nose. Light in profile, the dry palate offers a juicy melon flavor drizzled in a squeeze of lime. A slick of wet slate lingers on the finish.
Wine: Barnstormer 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Diffused aromas of tangerine and grapefruit peels abound in this single-vineyard Riesling sourced from a shale-laden vineyard on the western side of Seneca Lake. The palate is broad and juicy, yet dry, displaying flavors of fleshy yellow apple and white blossoms, with shots of orange acidity.
Wine: Bellangelo 2017 Kashong Glen Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: A firm texture and big, earthy black-fruit flavors give this full-bodied wine plenty of presence. It tastes of blackberry, cranberry and dark chocolate while it feels tannic and grippy on the palate. Merlot and Petite Sirah are the two main components in the blend.
Wine: Bonterra 2016 Equinox Made with Organic Grapes Red (California)

Review: A reduced oaky entry leads to edgy citrus-driven acidity and a high-strung, stony briny mineral character that beguiles. Green apple, quince and Meyer lemon offer subtle fruit elements that rise up to the overall earthiness.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 Cougar Rock Vineyard Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an intensely earthy, soft and stemmy red, savory and exotic in black tea, cardamom and citrus undertones. On top, expect dark cherry compote and wisps of pomegranate within a medium-bodied ripeness of style.
Wine: Bruliam 2016 Torrey Hill Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Franc and Cabernet Sauvignon each make up a third of this blend, with the balance equal parts Merlot and Petit Verdot. The aromas offer notes of high-toned cherry, graphite, flower and spice. The tannins bring a bit of grip and dryness, needing some time to soften.
Wine: Cadence 2015 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This lovely wine impresses on all counts. Affordable, beautifully proportioned and expressing well-defined, nicely layered flavors, it puts many far more expensive Chardonnays to shame. Elegant apple, pear, white peach and pineapple flavors intertwine, set up in a soft, lightly buttery frame.
Wine: Cardwell Hill 2017 Estate Bottled The Bard Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cream, spice and roasted squash aromas draw you into the glass. The palate is graceful and elegant, with impeccable balance to the stone fruit and pumpkin flavors throughout, along with a pretty sense of texture. A lingering finish caps it off. It walks the tightrope perfectly.
Wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2017 Mimi Chardonnay (Horse Heaven Hills)

Review: Made in small amounts, this white worth seeking. It's crunchy in green apple and quince, with a complementary cradling of caramel oak. The rich body weight is buoyed by bright acidity.
Wine: Chenoweth 2017 Bootlegger's Hill Chardonnay (Green Valley)

Review: This is 100% varietal and from the producer's vineyard, planted to two clones of the variety. Clove, caramel and dusty sage flavors guide a powerful, integrated body of full ripeness, soft texture and lasting richness of graham cracker.
Wine: Clif Family 2015 Cold Springs Vineyard Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Review: This is made from two of the producer's properties, Cold Springs and Croquet Estate, both atop the mountain appellation. It shows the power of those sites and a drought-driven vintage. The core is dense and tannic with an intensity of baked plum and dark chocolate.
Wine: Clif Family 2015 Kit's Killer Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Review: This blends a majority of Cabernet Sauvignon with smaller amounts of Merlot, Malbec and Petit Verdot. It delivers plenty of lush layered black-currant and black-cherry flavors around softened tannin and sweet vanilla oak.
Wine: Darioush 2014 Caravan Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A distinctly minty note informs this Dijon clone Chardonnay, along with light melon and apple fruit. It's firm through the midpalate, moving into a lingering, detailed finish. A touch of butter suggests some malolactic fermentation, but the remaining acidity is sufficient to keep it all in balance.
Wine: David Hill 2016 Estate Reserve Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Review: This is a relatively small-production sparkling blend of 51% Pinot Noir and 49% Chardonnay, aged more than three years in bottle. Creamy and lush on the palate, it contrasts that richness with focused acidity and crisp flavors of ginger and lemon.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2013 Estate Brut Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Pinot Gris from the southern region of state can attain a luscious fruitiness not found further north. This excellent wine offers a concentrated Bosc pear flavor that's dappled with cinnamon spice. Any dish featuring pears would be an ideal match.
Wine: Earth Song 2017 Estate Grown Pinot Gris (Southern Oregon)

Review: This wine shows good concentration in color, flavor and texture. It is deep and dark, with ripe, jammy tones of blackberry and black cherry. Significant baking-spice elements add complexity, while fine-grained tannins add a thick texture.
Wine: Educated Guess 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (North Coast)

Review: This is a meaty and thick wine, brimming in blueberry, violet and licorice. Full bodied and intensely ripe, it presents as smooth and richly woven on the palate.
Wine: Flanagan 2016 Syrah (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Quiet aromas of lemon and lime rinds hover over a core of fresh herbs and white cherry in this barrel-fermented Riesling. The palate offers creamy apple and tangerine peel flavors, peppered with a zesty limestone note and shot through with electric acidity. It's savory and lingering on the finish.
Wine: Fox Run 2017 Silvan Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Review: This is well made and big in style: a full-bodied, soft and round white offering an intensity of baked pineapple and mango. The spice component complements the bolder fruit and substantial oak, finishing in spicy nutmeg.
Wine: Frank Family 2016 Beckstoffer Carneros Lake Vineyard Reserve Chardonnay (Carneros)

Review: Reduced, tightly wound and densely packed, this is a big style of the variety, exotically marked by a wealth of citrus, cranberry and pomegranate flavors. Toasted oak supports the fruit.
Wine: Frank Family 2016 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Review: This wine is earthy, dusty and mineral-driven, with a lasting taste of dried herb, cedar and sage. Bright, underlying acidity lifts the midpalate from its full-bodied richness as red currant, cherry and cassis come into the light.
Wine: Frisson Wines 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This reserve bottling aims for richness, offering aromas of rounded apple, pear, smoked nuts and crushed chalk. The palate wraps a smoky touch around the dried grass and yellow-pear flavors.
Wine: Grassini 2016 Reserve Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted pork, nutmeg, vanilla and mulberry aromas show on the nose of this blend of 64% Grenache, 27% Syrah and 9% Petite Sirah, part of Napa winemaker Josh Phelps' new venture. It's smooth on the palate with loads of star anise and gingerbread flavors that play against a roasted red- and black-plum backdrop.
Wine: Grounded Wine Co. 2016 Public Radio Red (Paso Robles)

Review: Aromas of green pear and yellow apple ride over a core of lime rind on the nose of this off-dry Riesling. The palate is brisk yet well-textured, offering a creamy green melon flavor that's balanced by crunchy green pear and lime.
Wine: Hickory Hollow 2016 Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a robustly structured, energetic wine, robust in oak and spicy components. Leather and game give it an edginess of rough-hewn intensity, as white pepper contrasts well against flavors of strawberry and orange.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Hawk's Roost Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Lightly spiced and earthy, with a touch of tree bark and forest floor, this wine shines in tangy raspberry and strawberry flavors, with a backbone of sage and black tea. Light bodied and balanced, it has a persistence of acidity.
Wine: La Follette 2016 Heintz Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The balance here is tilted slightly toward Sémillon (54%). The nose offers notes of fig, lemon balm, spun cotton and citrus. Well-balanced, richly textured flavors follow, with tropical and citrus tones on the lingering finish. It needs some time to flesh out, but the stuffing is all there.
Wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2017 Estate Luminesce Seven Hills Vineyard Semillon-Sauvignon Blanc (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Review: Aromas of fig and spice carry the nose of this lush white. The palate brings a lovely sense of texture, with notes of honeycomb, fig and tropical fruit. A warm finish caps it off. Like most examples of this variety, it needs time in the bottle to be fully appreciated, but it has all the stuffing. Best after 2019.
Wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2017 Semillon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Blending in tiny amounts of Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Malbec, this robustly concentrated red is given nearly two years in French oak, much of it new. It offers leathery sinew, bombastic tannins that should shake out in time, and classic elements of cedar, pencil shavings and currant. This is for fans of power.
Wine: Melmar Wines 2015 Signature Edition Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A thick, layered and richly woven red from a well-farmed site, this speaks loudly to the vintage and the appellation, imparting lovely flavors of black cherry, black tea and cola. Fleshy and beguiling, it lingers in vanilla.
Wine: Migration 2016 Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: This is a broad-shouldered, richly unctuous white despite its un-oaked approach. Spicy ginger, ripe mango and pear are aligned with a lasting taste of caramel.
Wine: Pellet Estate 2016 Sun Chase Vineyard Un-Oaked Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Slate and stone mark this delicately earthy wine, with strikes of green apple and pear in the background. The off-dry palate shows a pleasing roundness, with flavors of green melon and yellow apple giving a juicy feel. Bright acidity keeps this buoyant and lively, while a slightly savory note marks the close.
Wine: Red Tail Ridge 2016 RTR Estate Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Sanguine in red currant and cherry, this full-bodied wine is juicy, soft and round, with polished tannins and integrated oak. It impresses with its ability to offer varietal character and overall approachability.
Wine: Rombauer 2015 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are light, with notes of red fruit, berry, fresh herb and whiffs of smoked meat. The palate shows an appealing sense of restraint, texture and balance that carries through the smoked meat finish. One wants a bit more aromatically, but the elegance of the palate delivers.
Wine: Structure 2016 Red Willow Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Review: This is a powerfully concentrated wine that's balanced by an underlying brightness. The juicy acidity supports flavors of red cherry and plum, while integrated tannins give it a plush feel that's widely appealing.
Wine: The Calling 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Review: The fresh, snappy fruit flavors in this medium-bodied wine are almost irrestible. It shows the charming, light and quaffable aspects of the grape that make it a good lunch wine or pre-dinner glass.
Wine: The Federalist 2016 Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine has a concentrated berry and cherry essence that makes it easy to sip and enjoy. A touch of raspberry in the aroma and a hint of baking spices on the palate make it all the more tasty.
Wine: Three 2016 Old Vines Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Review: This dry-style Riesling is all about texture. Pollen-dusted green melon and apple start off the nose, giving way to more creamy melon on the palate. This has a soft, silken feel that's balanced by a delicate framing of acidity. With its broad mouthfeel and savory finish, this is sure to be a welcome addition to the dinner table.
Wine: Trestle Thirty One 2016 Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Complementing its Whole Grape Ferment Rieslings, this barrel-fermented (on the skins) wine was aged a half-year in neutral wood. It offers scents of cinnamon spice and lean apple fruit. The racy minerality completes the picture and sets it stylistically apart from the winery's other Vermentino.
Wine: Troon 2017 Whole Grape Ferment Vermentino (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of yellow melon and orange cream make for a clean and plush nose in this blend of Grenache Blanc, Albariño, Loureiro and Viognier from the Estelle Vineyard. It's lush on the palate at first, and then tightens in structure, offering ripe but grippy flavors of creamy white peach and cherimoya.
Wine: McClain Cellars 2016 Kiss of Life White (Santa Ynez Valley)

Review: Dried herbs, dark red cherry, crushed slate and smashed twigs show on the nose of this bottling from the southern Paso Robles region. The herbaceous character is deftly integrated into the palate's black-cherry fruits, all framed by tight tannins.
Wine: Ancient Peaks 2016 Merlot (Santa Margarita Ranch)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's a strong kick of hickory to the nose of this bottling by a winery founded in 1933, with subtle black-cherry fruit slow to emerge. The palate offers a tight structure that evolves with time, proving light in body and tense with mellow rosewater flavors.
Wine: Bargetto 2017 Regan Vineyards Reserve Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: This blend of three properties from up and down the Central Coast (64% Rancho Solo, 24% Alta Loma and 12% Shokrian vineyards) is a bit gamy at first, but the red fruit and flower aromas emerge from the reductive veil with time. The palate offers flavors of roasted pork in a red-plum sauce, with a touch of oak.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2016 Grenache (Monterey County)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is a blend of 56% Merlot and 44% Cabernet Franc. The aromas are a bit reticent out of the gate, with notes of herb, flower and dark fruit. The palate features big, burly tannins that come off as a bit dry and wound up at present.
Wine: Cadence 2015 Bel Canto Cara Mia Vineyard Red (Red Mountain)

Review: In an outstanding portfolio of crisp, textural 2017 white wines, this is perhaps the most approachable. It's balanced and fresh, though not quite as bitingly tart as the winery's Pinot Blanc, or as crisply defined as the Auxerrois. Nonetheless a fine bottle, with ripe apple and pear fruit in a compact style.
Wine: Carlton Cellars 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Review: Elegant purple fruits meet with violet and lavender on the nose of this blend, which is led by Syrah, Tannat, Tempranillo and Grenache, with little bits of Viognier and Petite Sirah. Firm tannins uphold the medium-bodied palate, where tart berry and more purple-flower flavors arise.
Wine: Edna Valley Vineyard 2016 Red (Central Coast)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Intense and tarry in style, this bottling starts with deep aromas of boysenberry. There is a compelling density and intensity to the sip, where dark berries meet with damp tarragon flavors.
Wine: Figge 2015 Foster's Vineyard Sangiovese (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose of this bottling is very twiggy with aromas of dried herbs, dark cocoa, peppercorn and elderberry. Damp wood and sage sticks show on the palate alongside very dark and dry berry flavors.
Wine: La Honda Winery 2016 Salinian Block Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The cedar, sandalwood and pine-forest aromas work well on the Sangiovese in this bottling, which also shows red cherry on the nose. There is good tannic tightness to the palate, where red-fruit flavors meet with sawdust and vanilla on the finish.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2014 Therese Vineyards Dos Ninas Vineyard Sangiovese (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Clements Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This full-bodied and thick-textured wine wraps spicy smoky beefy flavors around a good core of blackberries and black cherries. The spicy oak character dominates but it's attractive and adds to the wine's boldness.
Wine: Odisea 2015 Lewis Vineyard The Temp Tempranillo (Clements Hills)

Appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Gorgeous fruit flavors meet darker clove notes in this exuberant but also well-structured and moderately tannic wine, made from a Rhône grape variety better known as Mourvèdre. Good acidity lifts the mouthfeel and keeps it tasting lively through the finish.
Wine: Riaza 2014 Prospector Monastrell (Calaveras County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Gobs of fruit flavor and a rich, rounded texture make this wine fun to taste and easy to enjoy. It practically oozes blackberry and black cherry flavors, and is supported by mild tannins and a velvety mouthfeel.
Wine: Sobon Estate 2016 Rocky Top Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A full, even fleshy wine, which puts a bit of barrel toast (15% was aged in wood) around plump pear fruit. It's well ripened and ready to drink while young and fresh.
Wine: Apolloni 2017 L Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Aromas of wet limestone, citrus zest and quince are tight and focused on the nose of this dry-style Riesling. Flavors of tart green-plum and lime are persistent on the palate, softened by some textural roundness and extended by a lingering marshmallow finish.
Wine: Bellangelo 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Very rich and ripe, this lip-smacking wine has abundant grapey jammy blackberry-like aromas and flavors, and a broad, mouthfilling texture. It's well-backed by moderate tannins to balance out all that fruit.
Wine: Collier Creek 2016 Big Rooster Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A soft velvety middle of muddled dark cherry, strawberry and black tea combines fruit and earth well in this medium-bodied estate wine. A touch of reduction persists from the beginning.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Manzana Vineyard Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Clean aromas of pomelo and lychee meet with peach and dried sour pear on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. Tangy citrus and grapefruit flavors ride an energetic mouthfeel, with a long-lasting acid that takes a sour stretch into the finish.
Wine: Jaffurs 2017 Bien Nacido Vineyard Viognier (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Eagle Peak, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This attractive medium- to full-bodied wine lays out tasty pear and vanilla aromas and adds a touch of butter wrapped in a soft low-acidity texture. It was aged in neutral barrels on the lees for nine months so it goes easy on the oakiness.
Wine: Masút 2017 Estate Chardonnay (Eagle Peak)

Review: A strong clover-honey aroma greets the nose and carries straight through the palate. This is luscious and well-concentrated, displaying juicy peach and citrus flavors that are drizzled with gobs of honey. Latent acidity balances this sweet wine out come the finish.
Wine: O-Neh-Da 2016 Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe tones of nectarine, peach and waxy honeycomb form on the nose. There's some textural roundness on the palate, bolstered by flavors of peach skin and chewy dried apricot. Despite these ripe fruit flavors, the finish is dry, ending on a delicate astringent sensation.
Wine: Sheldrake Point 2017 Estate Bottled Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of lemon cream and banana meet with a touch of chalk and a crushed rock minerality on the nose of this blend of 44% Grenache Blanc, 29% Viognier, 12% Marsanne, 12% Roussanne and 3% Clairette Blanche. There is a compelling tension to the palate, giving structure to the tropical guava and lime-spray flavors.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2017 Patelin de Tablas Blanc White (Paso Robles)

Review: This wine shows light aromas of plum and cinnamon before rich and mouthfilling plum and strawberry flavors coat the palate. It is medium to full in body, is not overly oaky and has good concentration and light tannins to keep it feeling snappy on the finish.
Wine: Tailor Made 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine looks deep and dark, smells like black fruits and tastes concentrated, ripe and nicely dry. It has firm tannins and good acidity to boost the texture and enough depth in the fruit flavors to last on the finish.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2014 Signature Tempranillo (Amador County)

Review: Aromas of hay and lawn clippings meet with wet river stone on the nose of this fresh and vibrant bottling. It's zippy on the palate, with flavors of lemon, lime and grapefruit rind.
Wine: Edna Valley Vineyard 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Central Coast)

Review: Candied cherries, hibiscus, sumac and light clove aromas show on the nose of this bottling from Southern California. Dried strawberry flavors meet with mint and garden herbs on the aromatic palate.
Wine: Europa Village 2014 Vienza Private Reserve Sangiovese (Temecula)

Appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine begins with ripe bubblegum, peach, pear-syrup and Stargazer lily aromas, although those start to fade into more mineral tones as it sits open. The sip is quite tight, with lemony acidity and a chalky frame constraining the peachy flavors.
Wine: Margerum 2017 Margerum Estate Vineyard Viognier (Los Olivos District)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Grenache makes up 60% of this wine, followed by Mourvèdre and Syrah. Perfumed tangerine peel, flower, white pepper, ash, green herb and raspberry aromas are followed by soft, supple, elegant red fruit flavors, laced with peppery accents. What's there is pretty, but the concentration seems light, especially in the middle.
Wine: Palencia 2016 Casa Amarilla G-S-M (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Brawny and rich, this is a stemmy and juicy wine, fruity in dark blueberry and blackberry fruit. Asian spice and cinnamon cola round out the full-bodied ripe experience.
Wine: Portalupi 2016 Dolinsek Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Wet cement, almond cream, nectarine and tuberose aromas show on the nose of this blend of 44% Viognier, 24% Marsanne, 20% Grenache Blanc and 12% Roussanne. There is a strong acidity to the sip, which is crisp and clean with sliced pear and a hint of guava flavors.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2017 Cotes de Tablas Blanc White (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine features plummy raisiny aromas and fresh grapey flavors on a smooth, almost soft texture. It's easy to sip and enjoy on its own due to low tannins.
Wine: Vino Noceto 2014 OGP Original Grandpere Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark-black-plum aromas are fresh but dense on the nose of this bottling, which also offers tarragon, tobacco and bay leaf scents. The eucalyptus streak is strong on the tip of the sip but then warms up into baked blackberry and black-cherry flavors.
Wine: Balderdash 2014 Brakelight Syrah (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A blossomy nose of lemongrass and gardenia starts off this dry-style Riesling. Notes of stone, citrus and tart peach give the palate a peppy feel, with a delicate astringent grip and a fine framing of acidity offering structure. Shots of wet stone and peach linger on the finish.
Wine: Benmarl 2016 Reserve Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Juicy in style, this blend of 45% Petit Verdot, 25% Merlot, 23% Malbec and 7% Cabernet Franc offers aromas of fresh-pressed blackberry and a hint of caramel. Charred oak, red-cherry and cranberry flavors arise on the palate alongside dried sage.
Wine: Bishop's Peak 2015 Elevation Red (Paso Robles)

Review: Seared lemon rinds, toasted almonds and broad apple aromas arise on the nose of this bottling. It's smooth and waxy on the palate with crème brûlée and Marcona almond flavors.
Wine: Black Ridge 2015 Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Farmed by Dai Crisp (Temperance Hill), this is a soft, lightly oxidized take on Pinot Gris. Round and smooth, with fresh flavors of pear flesh and skin, it carries a hint of cinnamon into the finish.
Wine: Brooks 2017 Logsdon Ridge Vineyard Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Boisterous aromas of peach, mango and melon carry to the medium-bodied palate. This semidry Riesling offers a solid concentration of creamy tropical-fruit flavors that are well-honed by pineapple and citrus acidity. This is straightforward in its appeal, yet the energy and balance keeps you coming back for more.
Wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2017 Semi-Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Named after Konstantin Frank's wife, this single-vineyard Riesling offers fresh tones of apple, apricot, lime peel and crushed stone on the nose. It's broad and juicy on the palate, displaying loads of crisp tree-fruit flavors that are balanced by delicate astringency. The finish is brisk, refreshing and dry.
Wine: Dr. Konstantin Frank 2017 Eugenia Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: This big wine strikes a good balance between ripe delicious fruit flavors and the notorious tannic bite of the varietal. Black cherry and blackberry fill the aroma and flavors, while a very firm texture gives them plenty of support.
Wine: Fiddletown Cellars 2015 Petite Sirah (Amador County)

Review: Dark red-cherry, boysenberry and rosebud aromas make for a deep and expressive style of Grenache on the nose of this bottling. There is a strong herbal touch to the palate, where thyme, sagebrush and cinnamon meet with snappy black-raspberry flavors.
Wine: Figge 2016 Grenache (Santa Ynez Valley)

Review: This full-bodied wine matches buttery, toasty overtones with plenty of juicy ripe pear and apple flavors. Aged on the lees for 10 months, the texture is smooth and layered, and there's a good hint of acidity to balance the wine's richness.
Wine: Gen5 2016 Chardonnay (Lodi)

Review: Refreshing and crisp, this light-bodied, elegant wine offers very clean appley aromas and good lean Bosc pear and mineral flavors backed by appetizing acidity.
Wine: Imagery 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (California)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bright and fruity red-currant and baked berry aromas blend with turned earth and mint-chocolate-chip aromas on the nose of this bottling. The palate's silky tannins and plush texture carry bright ripe fruit flavors with a hint of anise.
Wine: Indigené 2015 Ambiente Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rich aromas of plum and incense show on the herbaceous nose of this blend. It's taut in texture on the palate, where flavors of pine needle and dark red fruits ride a decent wave of acidity.
Wine: La Honda Winery 2016 Exponent Red (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: Black-cherry and mace aromas come through on a very ripe and extracted nose for this appellation blend. It's thick on the palate, with concentrated strawberry and raspberry flavors that are cut by dried herbs and framed by chalky tannins and penetrating acidity.
Wine: Left Bend 2015 Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: Aromas of red and black raspberry, cigar box, mandarin orange, dried herb, flower, white pepper and gummy bear are followed by light, soft, red fruit flavors. It has a pretty, elegant styling, with a lingering finish.
Wine: Palencia 2016 Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Review: Very concentrated and very tannic, this wine is young and tightly wound, so it will need plenty of time to reach peak enjoyment. The black-pepper, cranberry and espresso flavors are enticing but difficult to get to now. Best after 2025.
Wine: Parducci 2015 Small Lot Petite Sirah (Mendocino)

Review: A spicy nose with an herbal edge carries a faint impression of petrol, as a Riesling might show. In the mouth the flavors fill in and round out, with sweet pear, white peach, and more of that Germanic hint of petrol. An interesting wine, though done in a style that's atypical for Pinot Gris.
Wine: Spindrift Cellars 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Pollen dusted herbs and lime start off this delicate Riesling. The palate is slick in feel, displaying flavors of green melon rind, slate and lime juice, while a strong current of acidity keeps it alive and kicking. Pair with a meal to counteract all that zest.
Wine: Bellwether 2016 S Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine is delicious in terms of late-harvested fruit flavors like boysenberry jam and raspberry syrup. It has full body, mild tannins and a mouthcoating texture.
Wine: Binz 2015 Fox Creek Vineyard Zinfandel (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A fresh, focused nose of grapefruit peel, peach and quince starts off this dry-style Riesling. It's taut on the palate, with an astringent grip of peach and apricot skins that is shot through with bright citrus acidity.
Wine: Fox Run 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A delicate nose of yellow apple, stone fruit and a dusting of pollen starts off this dry-style Riesling. The palate is crisp and chalky in texture, displaying a fleshy orchard-fruit flavor that's struck against a lime peel backdrop.
Wine: Hickory Hollow 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Cayuga Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A well-formed nose of apricot and white blossoms carries to the juicy yet dry palate. Ripe stone fruit mixes with shots of astringent grapefruit pith, while bright acidity helps extend a powdered mineral finish.
Wine: Hosmer 2017 Dry Riesling (Cayuga Lake)

Review: Boysenberry sorbet, cocoa and sweet dried herbs show on the nose of this complex and layered Cab from the warm reaches of Carmel Valley. The structure is tannic, chalky and firm, though the mouthfeel is lighter than expected, offering flavors of tobacco, berry and light vanilla on the finish.
Wine: Joullian 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Carmel Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Blackberry and raspberry flavors fight for attention against the tarry asphalt-laced nose of this bottling, which also shows off sage and anise aromas. Roasted wood and thyme flavors arise on the palate against elderberry and black-plum flavors.
Wine: Left Bend 2015 Gali Vineyard Syrah (Santa Cruz County)

Review: This estate-grown wine is made with whole-cluster fermentation, intended to be slower and cooler in order to produce less bitter tannin. It succeeds though does offer a stemmy carbonic expression that tastes of fresh strawberry and ash, the earthiness intense and persistent.
Wine: Marimar Estate 2015 Metodo Antiguo Dona Margarita Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: This wine is exotic and extroverted thanks to the aroma of wood char and singed rosemary, the bold black-fruit, the roasted coffee and the cocoa nib flavors. It's not overly full in body, and has good acidity and firm tannins for structure, which helps power the bold flavors on the palate and finish.
Wine: Shannon 2015 Home Ranch Reserve Tempranillo (Lake County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Wallula (66%), Red Willow (22%) and Destiny Ridge vineyards. Light aromas of blue and black fruit with crushed gravel, spice and green herb accents are followed by soft, silky blue fruit flavors. It shows a pretty sense of styling and balance.
Wine: Structure 2016 Foundation Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Thick, rich and robust in peach, apricot and stone, this is made in a big viscous style with present ripeness.
Wine: Andretti 2016 Pinot Grigio (Napa Valley)

Review: Black-cherry, vanilla and cola-syrup aromas show on the nose of this widely available wine. That richness dries up a bit on the sip thanks to upright, slightly sticky tannins, allowing flavors of strawberry and tart black-plum skin to shine through.
Wine: Austerity 2017 Pinot Noir (Monterey)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Tasted blind this could pass for Pinot Blanc, a near neighbor in France. It's a fresh, crisp white wine with a solid minerality under a mix of celery, lime and melon.
Wine: Björnson 2017 Viola Auxerrois (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light in the glass, this blend of 61% Grenache Blanc, 32% Viognier and 7% Picpoul offers approachable aromas of ripe apples, poached pear and light smoke. The palate is broad with very ripe flavors of roasted apple and pear, cut by a lime-pith edge.
Wine: Chronic Cellars 2017 Stone Fox White (Paso Robles)

Review: Robust tannin and oak wraparound a full expression of red cherry and vanilla in this soft, approachable blend.
Wine: Decoy 2016 Red (Sonoma County)

Review: Somewhat shy on the nose, this bottling offers berry, dried herb and wet slate aromas. The palate is very dry and tightly woven with chalky tannins that only allow berry, roast beef and charcoal flavors to barely arise. It will likely become more expressive with time.
Wine: Donati Family Vineyard 2015 Family Reserve Malbec (Paicines)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crushed slate, oregano and blackberry-syrup aromas show on the nose of this blend. Ripe cherries and strawberries provide an approachable, nearly sweet core to the palate, which benefits from a pinch of herbs.
Wine: Edna Valley Vineyard 2015 Winemaker Series Meritage (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Light aromas of pomegranate and cherry meet with licorice on the nose of this bottling. Cola-spice and strawberry-juice flavors make for a pleasant fruit-punch-like sipping experience.
Wine: Europa Village 2015 Bolero Cellars Garnacha (Temecula Valley)

Review: Fresh, crisp flavors tilt toward green produce—daikon radish, celery and yellow apple. There's a dash of white pepper and a finishing hint of brioche.
Wine: Foris 2017 Pinot Blanc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of pineapple upside-down cake, spice and caramel are followed by ripe but in check full-bodied tropical fruit flavors that persist on the toasty finish. The alcohol shows a bit prominently, but the fruit is nice.
Wine: Gorman 2017 Big Sissy Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Warm aromas of cherry and chalk start off this pink wine from Happy Canyon. It's easy on the palate with light red-fruit flavors and a soft quaffable texture.
Wine: Grassini 2017 Afiora Rosé (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Review: Mild-mannered fruit is dominated by substantial tannin weight and concentration, with savory elements of clove and black tea playing around the edges.
Wine: Jigar 2014 Graham Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Light aromas of cedar and spice are followed by supple black fruit flavors and grainy tannins. It comes off as quite ripe.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2016 Scooteney Flats Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Red Mountain)

Review: Clean aromas of Asian pear rind, lime and chalk make for a very tightly woven nose on this bottling. Apple and pear-juice flavors dominate the broad palate.
Wine: Lucas & Lewellen 2017 Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)

Review: Aged 10 months in neutral American oak, this wine has a thick gritty texture and a sweetness of peach, green apple and honey. The structure and acidity are moderate; the ripeness full bodied and intense.
Wine: Mengler Family Wines 2017 Hoot Owl Creek Vineyard Viognier (Alexander Valley)

Review: Long Island Riesling is few and far between, however this example is relatively solid. It is taut and liner in feel, with delicate flavors of wet limestone, lime zest and white blossoms. The concentration is light, yet it's zesty and refreshing.
Wine: Paumanok 2017 Riesling (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a meaty white, layered in dried herb and white peach. The texture is youthful and still evolving.
Wine: Quivira 2017 Fig Tree Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Solid and expressive, this vintage of Big Fire offers big fruit. Plush pear, apple and peach flavors are underscored by a hint of lime. It's a wine to drink young and slightly chilled.
Wine: R. Stuart & Co. 2017 Big Fire Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Review: A touch of seeming-sweetness from generous oak treatment spices up the aromas and flavors of this ripe and generous-tasting wine. It has lots of plums and cherries in addition to a mapley baking-spice component.
Wine: Sean Minor 2017 4B Pinot Noir (California)

Review: This is a reduced, tight and robustly ripe wine, grippy in structure and a lasting taste of black pepper and gunpowder. Black-licorice, black-cherry and blackberry flavors round out the experience.
Wine: Waypoint 2014 Oakville Ranch Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas of this wine are light, with notes of herb, grass, citrus and lemon balm. The palate is more giving, with sleek but textured lemony flavors.
Wine: Woodward Canyon 2017 Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Review: Strong aromas of Anjou pear, honeysuckle and almond make for an aromatic entry to the nose of this bottling, which halts malolactic fermentation halfway through to preserve freshness. The palate is indeed fresh, with flavors of apple and white flowers.
Wine: Wrath 2016 Fermata Chardonnay (Monterey)

Review: Broad aromas of fruit punch, pomegranate, sumac, mace and rust show on the nose of this fairly priced bottling from the Miller family of Bien Nacido Vineyard. It's bright, snappy and tangy with red-plum skin, strawberry and raspberry flavors on the palate, plus herbs and pepper spice.
Wine: Ballard Lane 2017 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black cherry, wet loam, damp cedar and a pinch of cocoa show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very tense with tannins and searing acid, though intense boysenberry flavors do peek through.
Wine: Bargetto 2016 Regan Vineyards Reserve Merlot (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: This wine is big, bold and densely textured. Ripe blackberry and violet aromas lead to rich saturated fruit flavors, very little oakiness and a very full mouthfeel boosted by layered tannins.
Wine: Berryessa Gap 2016 Durif (Yolo County)

Review: Crushed sandstone and flinty mineral aromas meet with a slightly reductive nose on this bottling. The palate is very tightly wound with grassy lime-skin flavors.
Wine: Black Ridge 2014 Viognier (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: From a 1984 planting, this is listed as medium dry but shows noticeable sweet, somewhat sugary fruit flavors. The mix of sugar, acid and biting skin flavors is a bit jagged at this point, and the finish shuts down abruptly. Give it another year or two in the bottle and it should pull those well-made components together.
Wine: Brooks 2016 Yamhill Vineyard Riesling (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From an New York operation located in the Hudson Valley that bills itself as the oldest continuously operating winery in the country, this bottling shows baked cherries, blackberries, molasses and anise on the nose. It's rounded and rich on the palate, where charred red fruits meet with cocoa atop a decently structured texture.
Wine: Brotherhood 2014 1839 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This barrel-fermented (one-sixth new), single-clone, estate-grown wine has pleasant but light flavors of fresh apple. The concentration of the previous vintage is missing, but the balance is fine, with hints of buttery toast in the finish.
Wine: Carabella 2016 Dijon 76 Estate Chardonnay (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine is very fruity and also well-structured, offering generous raspberry and blackberry flavors backed by moderate tannins and good acidity. It's well balanced and appetizing to taste.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2016 Estate Primitivo (El Dorado)

Review: Rich aromas of dark plum, sagebrush, cola and black cherry make for a rather thick and ripe aromatic entry to this appellation blend. It is also thick on the palate, where dark-cherry flavors make for a ripe and structured experience.
Wine: Cinnabar 2015 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Review: This is a value-driven blend that delivers plenty of quality flavor for the price, including an explosion of juicy dark cherry, cassis and rich round nicely integrated oak and tannin. It's enjoyable now and sure to please a crowd.
Wine: Decoy 2015 Red (Sonoma County)

Review: Oily and oaky, this white is light bodied and viscous, featuring layered flavors of green apple, lemon and wet stone.
Wine: Domenica Amato 2017 Ceja Farms Grenache Blanc (Sonoma Coast)

Review: This is estate-grown wine, crisp and sharply tense in acidity, the flavors marked by a distinction of green apple, pear and pineapple. The oak is measured and unobtrusive.
Wine: Etude 2016 Grace Benoist Ranch Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This tangy, tasty wine will appeal greatly to those who favor highly acidic, lemony whites. The lip-licking acidity conjures up a citrus mix of grapefruit, lemon and orange. It was fermented in stainless and picked at low pH to emphasize the juicy acidity.
Wine: Five Fourteen Vineyards 2017 Estate Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Review: This full-bodied white has an intensity of oak and baked fruit, which is a combination of apple and pear. Aromas of nutmeg accentuate the richness and warmth of the overall experience.
Wine: J. McClelland 2015 Chardonnay (Oak Knoll District)

Review: The aromatics from these biodynamically grown grapes are compelling, though in the mouth the flavors fall a bit short of completely ripened fruit. Apple skin, citrus pith and a touch of grapefruit are on display. Despite 14 months on the lees, the mouthfeel flattens out through the finish. Best consumed now through 2020.
Wine: Keeler 2016 Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Fresh aromas of apple and quince show a delicate grip on the nose, leading to a textured palate that's peppered with tonic water. The acidity is drawing yet well-honed, giving a wine that's refreshing, crisp and begging to be served alongside food.
Wine: Lamoreaux Landing 2017 Yellow Dog Vineyard Estate Bottled Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Equal parts Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon aged for 20 months in new American oak. The aromas are lighter styled, with notes of dark fruit and abundant barrel spice. Ripe, rich black fruit flavors that pack a big punch follow. It seems a bit one note, but what's there is quite nice.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2016 Heritage Reserve Red Wine Syrah-Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Review: The aromas are generous, with notes of melon, white flower, pear and peach. The apricot and peach flavors are full bodied, sweet, ripe and nectarous with a warm finish. It delivers a lot of appeal, though the apparent residual sugar runs a bit high.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Viognier (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Sweet notions of peach and nectarine mark this fleshy, creamy rich and round sparkler, textured with an undeniable lushness. Both Chardonnay and Pinot Noir go into the blend.
Wine: Mumm Napa NV Cuvée M Sparkling (Napa County)

Review: Tart, tangy acidity is persistent through this wine's full-bodied character of robust dark-red fruit, black tea and dried herb. It offers richness and ripeness.
Wine: Peter Paul Wines 2016 Gravenstein Highway Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Review: White peach, banana, lemon wedge and tropical fruits show on the nose of this bottling of a grape rarely seen in California. There is a flash of sweetness at the tip of the sip, followed by tingly acidity and pome-fruit flavors.
Wine: Rancho Sisquoc 2017 Sylvaner (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Mokelumne River, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This bold and full-bodied wine has ripe jammy Port-like aromas, plump blackberry flavors and a rich, almost-sweet, palate impression. It's certainly mouth coating and tooth staining.
Wine: Riaza 2015 Unorthodox Syrah (Mokelumne River)

Review: This Cabernet Sauvignon-based blend includes smaller amounts of Malbec, Merlot, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc, in that order. Together, they offer a robust, oaky and soft expression of mild blue and black fruit, dusted in toasted oak and tobacco.
Wine: Rodney Strong 2014 Symmetry Meritage (Alexander Valley)

Review: Spicy clove and black pepper adorn a burly build of subdued black fruit in this reserve-level wine. The finish is soft and moderate.
Wine: Rutherford Ranch 2016 Reserve Malbec (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crushed rocks, black currant, caramel and toasty oak make for a bright, minerally entry to this blend of 38% Cabernet Sauvignon, 38% Syrah and 24% Petite Sirah. Sour black-plum flavors meet with lilac on the palate.
Wine: Sculpterra 2015 Statuesque Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This wine has a good range of fruit, spice and wood flavors along with appealing balance and a smooth, lightly tannic texture. Hints of cedar, black cherry and raspberry light up the palate.
Wine: Urgency 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Review: Very shy aromas of black raspberry show on the nose of this bottling. Tart black-plum and elderberry flavors meet with dried herbs on the palate, but the overall expression is very mellow and reserved.
Wine: Wolff 2015 Syrah (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bay leaf, tarragon, black-plum sauce and Asian spices show on the sharp nose of this bottling. There's a rich streak of boysenberry to the palate as well as juniper and pine needle touches. Still needs time to evolve.
Wine: Wrath 2016 Tondré Grapefield Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: It's easy to like this generous, fruity and plush-textured wine based on French grape varieties, led by 45% Tannat and followed by Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Raspberry and blackberry aromas and flavors are lightly shaded by spicy oak notes and there is a moderate dose of tannin to balance the jammy fruit character.
Wine: Y Rousseau 2016 Son of a Butcher Red (California)

Review: Unoaked and showing flavors of green apple flesh and peel. There's a pleasing sharpness to the mouthfeel. Flavors penetrate and linger, suggesting a match to any and all white fish in a butter sauce.
Wine: A to Z 2017 Chardonnay (Oregon)

Review: Flower, soil, herb, spice and black cherry aromas lead to ripe dark fruit flavors that taper ever so slightly toward the cocoa-filled finish. There is a lot to like.
Wine: Barnard Griffin 2016 Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Defined aromas of grapefruit and crisp apple start off this semidry Riesling. A solid concentration of stone fruit and apple flavors marks the palate, with a frame of bright acidity to keep the balance.
Wine: Bellangelo 2016 Morris Vineyard Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Review: Slate and smoke mask a core of peach juice and crushed tangerine on the nose of this semidry Riesling. The palate is a well-blended mix of ripe stone fruit, sugar-dusted blossoms and sour green apple, with a pillowy, marshmallow finish.
Wine: Bellangelo 2016 Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Ripe and lush, this full-bodied wine practically oozes raspberry and sweet cherry flavors. The texture is very smooth and polished too.
Wine: Berryessa Gap 2016 Zinfandel (Yolo County)

Review: Dried sage, bay leaf and thyme play against red cherry, raspberry and white pepper on the nose of this affordably priced twist-top bottling from the Talleys. Crushed carnations and tart cranberry flavors meet with orange rind on the palate.
Wine: Bishop's Peak 2016 Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Violets, lilacs, black fruits and star anise make for a very showy nose on this blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Malbec. Very floral flavors arise on the sip, where grainy tannins carry ripe black-plum-paste flavors.
Wine: Black Ridge 2013 San Andreas Red (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: With a copper-orange hue, this is made from a majority of Pinot Noir though it offers flavors indicative of the Chardonnay content as well. Driven by citrus tones of tangerine, it has a dry gritty texture, mid-level structure and lasting acidity.
Wine: Breathless NV Blanc de Noirs Sparkling (Sonoma County)

Review: Green pepper, green herb, jalapeño and black cherry aromas are followed by sleek, fresh, well-balanced fruit flavors. One wants a bit more concentration but what's there is pleasing, accented by tart, lively acidity.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2016 Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: This is quality wine in a can, with no metallic flavor, just pretty, plush flavors of apple, melon and pear. The convenience of cans makes it easy to chill, pack, open and recycle.
Wine: Canned Oregon NV Oregon White Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light aromas of honeydew and honey show on the restrained nose of this bottling. The palate is all about a tight texture, with springtime flavors of white flowers and lime pith showing through.
Wine: Castoro Cellars 2017 Dos Vinas Vineyard Reserve Viognier (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Sweet and dark aromas of blackberry, dark chocolate, mint and charcoal show on the nose of this bottling. It's quite thick on the palate with strong tannins that cut the extracted black-currant and cigar-box flavors.
Wine: Clos La Chance 2014 Reserve Malbec (Central Coast)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Honey-drizzled apple and white blossoms start off this semisweet wine. It's ripe on the palate, with luscious flavors peach and melon that end on a caramel tone.
Wine: Damiani 2016 Semi-Sweet Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Clean honeydew, lime balm and peach-orange aromas meet with vanilla and white-rock aromas on the nose of this bottling. There is a flash of sweetness to the palate, where ripe apple and pear flavors combine with lemon syrup.
Wine: Ferguson Crest 2017 Viognier (Santa Barbara County)

Review: As with all of the Foris white wines, refreshing minerality and an overall sense of immaculate fruit preservation are foremost. The supporting minerality emphasizes focused flavors of cucumber and jicama through a refreshing finish.
Wine: Foris 2017 Pinot Gris (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: South Coast, South Coast, California, US
Review: Boysenberry, mocha, tar, roasted meat and mint show on the nose of this bottling from southern California. Rocky tarry flavors arise on the palate, with a slightly primary boysenberry-juice backbone.
Wine: Hawk Watch Winery 2015 Solo Barrique Syrah (South Coast)

Review: Sourced from from Quintessence Vineyard, this wine offers aromas of toast, fig, lemon balm and herb. These tones echo on the full-bodied palate but dip a little in concentration.
Wine: Henry Earl 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Red Mountain)

Review: High-toned acidity lifts a delicate offering of cinnamon, plum and blueberry in this soft, round and approachable red.
Wine: Kalaris 2014 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Review: This wine delivers substantial bang for the buck, blending a majority of Merlot with sizable amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, and small drops of Petit Verdot and Malbec. Firm tannins grip flavors of sage, cedar and graphite, with smoky blackberry playing on the full-bodied palate.
Wine: Kirkland Signature 2015 Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a monster wine that goes for broke in terms of big bold flavors, full body and massive tannins. The color is black almost to the rim, the aromas are peppery and espresso-like, while the flavors are full of black fruit but also tightly strapped in by tannins. The wine could open up with extended aging, so it's best to drink after 2025.
Wine: Lava Cap 2015 Reserve Petite Sirah (El Dorado)

Review: Aromas of lees, squash, custard, nut, candy corn and spice lead to full-bodied fruit flavors. There's a lovely sense of texture that piques the interest.
Wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2017 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated blackberry syrup, lilac, caramel and cedar show on the nose of this bottling. There is a strong cigar-box element to the palate, but it works with the rich black-currant flavors, all framed by tense tannins.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2015 Therese Vineyards Dos Ninas Vineyard Syrah (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Nevada County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has lots of fruit, light oak spices and a firm, lightly tannic texture. Raspberries and raisins are the key flavors and though almost sweet, they are balanced by good acidity and grippy tannins.
Wine: Naggiar 2016 Il Nonno Estate Reserve Red (Nevada County)

Review: Full bodied and firm textured, this wine offers plenty of fruit flavor, light oak shadings from the use of 30% new oak barrels and a good grippy mouthfeel.
Wine: Oak Farm 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Review: This spicy oaky wine is not quite sweet, but is packed full of strawberry jam, maple syrup and Maraschino cherry flavors that give it an exuberant, fruity personality. It has good fruit acidity and light tannins to add some textural counterpoint to the jamminess.
Wine: Precision Wine 2016 Navigator Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Barnyardy earth and leather combine around spicy, robust tannin and a wealth of full-bodied fruit. Black cherry and strawberry take on ripe bold richness that persist throughout the rich palate.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Black Label Nunes Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: Smoky oak and a hint of citrus combine in complementary ways in this earthy, rich and full-bodied red. Cherry-cola and vanilla flavors provide a burly fruity experience on the boldly built palate.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Purple Label Silver Pines Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black cherry and woody cedar aromas show strongly on the nose of this blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Cabernet Franc and 25% Merlot. It's quite thick and stiff on the palate, where the wood spice overtakes the dark-cherry fruit.
Wine: Sculpterra 2015 Maquette Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This wine is 100% varietal, with all of the fruit coming from Stillwater Creek Vineyard. Aromas of char, roasted coffee bean, fresh herb and cherry lead creamy-feeling fruit and barrel flavors, with toast and coffee notes lingering on the finish. The barrel influence seems overweighted for the fruit that's in the bottle, but there are good things going on if it settles in.
Wine: Sightglass 2016 Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Inviting aromas of Bing cherries, star anise, mace, tobacco and wood spice show on the nose of this blend. There's a strong herbal kick on the earthy palate, where turned loam and red-cherry flavors arise.
Wine: Sola 2015 Meritage (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas lack a sense of clarity, with notes of boysenberry and blue fruit lurking in the background. The palate is lighter styled but well proportioned, tapering toward the finish. The flavors are very pretty, but the aromas don't seem to sync up at present.
Wine: Structure 2016 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Review: Production of this workhorse Pinot Gris tops 66,000 cases, but the quality remains consistently good and the price looks more and more like a bargain as comparable wines creep upward in cost. Precisely layered flavors of apple, pear and white melon comprise the palate, with a gentle touch of spice.
Wine: A to Z 2017 Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Soft aromas of pollen-dusted apple and peach meet a sheen of spring ramps on the nose. This semisweet offering is light in feel, with flavors of juicy melon and tart yellow apple that are backed by wet stone and citrus.
Wine: Anthony Road 2017 Semi-Sweet Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Review: Earthy aromas of gravelly minerality, clay and damp wood meet with tart red currants on the nose of this lightly bodied Cab from a historic vineyard. There is a lot of herbal tension to the palate, which is fairly green and framed by tannins that still need smoothing out.
Wine: Buttonwood Farm 2013 Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Ynez Valley)

Review: This warm, spicy wine has a good combination of ripe red and black-fruit and generous dashes of baking spices. It is full in body, tastes ripe and has a firm but smooth texture.
Wine: Castle Rock 2017 Cuvée Pinot Noir (California)

Review: Concentrated and fruity, this full-flavored wine shows bright berry aromas, deep and ripe blackberry flavors and a texture that has a good little bite of tannin.
Wine: Cinnabar 2015 Mercury Rising Red (California)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fermented in 75% stainless and 25% neutral oak, this clean, simple wine mixes flavors of apple and pear. There are light hints of vanilla and water cracker. It's a pleasant wine at a modest price.
Wine: David Hill 2017 Estate Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Review: Robust on the palate, this wine opens in floral aromatics of jasmine and apple blossom. It follows flavorfully in Meyer lemon zest, tangerine and pineapple, combining firm structure with rounded approachability.
Wine: Folie à Deux 2017 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of graphite, cherry, medicine cabinet and cedar are followed by black fruit flavors that seem surprisingly light, especially in the middle, for the appellation and listed alcohol. Cranberry notes linger on the finish.
Wine: Gorman 2016 Old Scratch Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe aromas of peach, pineapple and mango carry a bit of a banana undercurrent in this dry-style Riesling. The medium-bodied palate is soft and fruity, with a creamy feel that's honed by balancing acidity.
Wine: Hazlitt 1852 Vineyards 2017 Homestead Reserve Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tangy red-cherry aromas are lifted by anise and nutmeg on the nose of this bottling, which features a whimsical but accurate geographic label. Bay leaf and thyme flavors give depth to the sharp pomegranate fruit flavors of the palate.
Wine: Inconceivable 2015 The Fog Prince Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Review: Blended with 14% Cabernet Franc, this succeeds in its light-bodied palate of red currant, cranberry and plum, with secondary characteristics of pencil shavings and graphite. The midpalate is thick and concentrated, finishing with elegance.
Wine: J. McClelland 2014 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Review: Ripe cherry aromas meet with cinnamon and sagebrush on the rustic yet approachable nose of this bottling. Tart red-fruit and turned earth flavors are framed by a clay-like texture on the palate.
Wine: Lucas & Lewellen 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The pine-forest aromas are strong in this bottling, with some blackberry, tobacco and eucalyptus also at play on the nose. Cedary, cigar-box flavors consume the palate, along with touches of blackberry and peppercorn.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2014 Therese Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied blackberry, tangy black plum and cedar show on the nose of this single-variety Petit Verdot, which is a slowly growing category. Robust black-currant and violet flavors are juicy if somewhat simple on the palate.
Wine: Midnight 2014 Synnove Petit Verdot (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Clements Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a very good, easy-drinking wine that smells and tastes generously fruity. It has a smooth and lightly tannic texture that will help it pair well with food. Graciano grapes made 74% of the blend, followed by Tempranillo, Grenache and Zinfandel in descending proportions.
Wine: Riaza 2014 Diablo Rojo Red (Clements Hills)

Appellation: Lake Chelan, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas leap out of the glass, displaying notes of slightly wilted white flower, ginger, mandarin orange zest and spice. This is a hair off-dry, with plenty to like.
Wine: Rocky Pond 2017 Clos CheValle Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Lake Chelan)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of extracted kirsch and loamy soils show on the nose of this rich bottling. Ripe cherry, oak and nutmeg aromas are evident on the palate.
Wine: Sarah's Vineyard 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Santa Clara Valley)

Review: This is a smoky oaky wine with a touch of reduction that opens into a juicy approachable world of soft rich blueberry and plum. It offers good value with a light-bodied approach to ripeness.
Wine: Sean Minor 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Review: This wine opens in floral element of rose before unleashing smoky edges and a leathery texture. Inside its full-bodied concentration lies earthy oak and black-cherry vanilla.
Wine: Sonoma-Loeb 2016 Sangiacomo Vineyard Fedrick Ranch Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: There's no mistaking the variety, with its aromas of fresh herb, black cherry, dark fruit and baking spice. Ripe fruit flavors follow, threaded with green herb notes throughout. Firm tannins provide support. The concentration isn't always there but what is is quite nice.
Wine: Structure 2016 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
