Supple berry fruit is backed by barrel spices (50% new French oak was used). Streaks of cola and cocoa ride out the finish, with supple, polished tannins.
Wine: Shea 2016 Shea Vineyard Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Smoked almonds, wood spice, peach and Meyer lemon preserves show on the nose of this bottling, which comes from vines planted in 1997. It's very tightly wound on the palate, with plenty of peach, mango and salted lemon flavors riding balanced acidity.
Wine: Tantara 2016 Dierberg Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: Possibly the most sought-after vineyard in the Willamette Valley. Shea fruit shines everywhere. This example is delineated with lively aromas of roses and raspberries. A taut, earthy flavor of beetroot runs through the palate, with a kiss of cinnamon coming up in the finish. This wine should continue to improve over many years. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Bergström 2016 Shea Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black cherry, black plum and violet aromas make for a deep, intense yet elegantly balanced nose on this bottling from the legendary vineyard. Candied cherry and boysenberry flavors show on the sip alongside black and purple sage, all wrapped in compelling tannic tension.
Wine: Bernardus 2016 Pisoni Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The aromas aren't quite ready to reveal their charms on first pour, with notes of strawberry, smoked meat, ground rock and crushed flower emerging over time. The flavors are light but sumptuous, showing a lovely sense of texture.
Wine: Cayuse 2015 God Only Knows Red (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Review: Again in 2016 this is the ripest of the winery's Pinots, and it spent almost a year in one-third new French oak. The color is a plummy purple/red, and the well-integrated flavors mix red and blue fruits, with a light dusting of cocoa. The lingering finish adds streaks of mocha and caramel.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2016 Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made from Pommard and Dijon clones of Pinot Noir, this is a snappy, lip-smacking wine, loaded with tangy raspberry and blueberry flavors. Highlights of cola, tea and subtle streaks of savory notes contribute to the overall length and complexity.
Wine: Elk Cove 2016 Clay Court Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Review: Supple purple fruits show perfect ripeness while rounding off in a lovely and satisfying midpalate. Barrel aging contributes a streak of espresso. Accents of black olive and clean earth are carefully moderated by smooth, polished tannins.
Wine: Elk Cove 2016 Mount Richmond Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a thick, even meaty Chardonnay with plenty of power. It rolls through well-integrated scents and flavors of lemon verbena, chervil and both green and yellow apples. The balance is impeccable, and the length and detail promise another eight to 10 years of drinking pleasure. It finishes with a soft hint of butter.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 Bunker Hill Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Review: From a site that sits at 1,600-feet in elevation, this wine is rich, round and ripe, as well as slightly reduced, and tightly wound in its youth. Leather, graphite and diesel wrap around a peppery, exotic core of dark chocolate and brambly blackberry that's ever changing in the glass. Enjoy best 2026–2030.
Wine: Rock Wall 2016 Monte Rosso Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: One senses a bit of friendly competition between the husband (Steve of Steve's Reserve) and wife (Flora) who own this property. The nod in 2015 goes to Flora, for this elegant, sophisticated wine with old vine grace and detail. A cascade of aromas and following flavors trail orange peel, honey, plum, cherry, chocolate and sweet spices. The texture and length are superb, with fine balance throughout.
Wine: Ruby 2015 Flora's Reserve Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Review: A longtime farming family debuts the first wines of its own with this impressively lush, plush white, tropical in flavor and seasoned in vanilla oak. Expansive on the palate, it manages to uphold tight, firm acidity throughout.
Wine: Sangiacomo 2016 Home Ranch Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a mix of Pommard and Dijon 115 clones, 18% whole cluster fermented, and aged in 60% new French oak. It's a ripe mouthful of blackberry and black cherry, backed with ample acidity and beautifully managed tannins. As it rolls into a lengthy finish more flavors compound—black olives, toast, coffee, chocolate and, finally, black tea tannins. Drink now through the 2020s.
Wine: Shea 2016 Shea Vineyard West Hill Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a steep vineyard near the eastern edge of the appellation, this effort by Santa Rosa-based Adam Lee offers composting rose petals, bright red cherry and a hint of game on the nose. There's a gamy kick to the palate as well, giving depth to the cherry and dried ginger flavors.
Wine: Siduri 2016 John Sebastiano Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The reserve, compiled with grapes from all three estate vineyards, seems to have a higher percentage of new oak, showing plenty of sweet spice in the nose and on the palate. Blueberry and cherry flavors, along with highlights of malted chocolate, gather into a concentrated core. The finish is a long, lingering jaunt with a touch of spice cake. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Trisaetum 2016 Estates Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The mouthfeel on this wine is simply lovely, and the mix of purple and black fruits comes with sappy acidity. There's a streak of iron, reflecting the terroir of the Ribbon Ridge AVA, and tannins are firm and ripe and set up a lingering finish.
Wine: Trisaetum 2016 Ribbon Ridge Estate Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Review: Cool-climate Petite Sirahs are an utter rarity, yet like cool-climate Syrah, they show an amazingly savory character when bottled. This wine starts with tar, peppercorn, cola-spice and boysenberry aromas that lead into a vibrant palate of pepper, roasted lamb and dark fruit. Energetic and fresh.
Wine: Wolff 2016 Petite Sirah (Edna Valley)

Review: A limited personal project from De Ponte winemaker Isabelle Dutartre, this elegantly finessed wine reveals ripe raspberry and Bing cherry fruit, subtly backed with 30% new French oak. It's a lighter style in the best possible way, and yet sturdy enough for long-term cellaring. Drink now–2030 and beyond.
Wine: 1789 Wines 2014 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Aged as before for 16 months in 38% new oak, this is dense and detailed, though clearly still in a primary phase and pulling itself together. Sassafras, brambly fruit and baking spices are all in the mix, with a touch of hot pepper candy in the finish. Drink 2020 to 2030.
Wine: Anne Amie 2015 Two Estates Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Aromatically lovely, this sappy, juicy wine is loaded with ripe, late-summer berry flavors. It's concentrated and lingering, in a most delicious style, with the complexity and pure power of the vintage. Drink now through 2025.
Wine: Archery Summit 2015 Premier Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Review: Blessed with 3% Petit Verdot, this wine represents the appellation with class and style, showing lush, smooth layers of crowd-pleasing complexity. With underlying elegance and a sense of balance, it offers red and black-cherry flavors alongside richer teases of mocha and tobacco.
Wine: Bellacosa 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This sappy, silky, supple selection focuses on black fruits and blacker barrel flavors. Cherry, licorice, tar, char and espresso combine, all in proportion and without showing any burnt edges. The big ripe fruit packs a punch.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2016 Justice Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: Lavish aromas of vanilla and pound cake with a black-currant frosting show with a pinch of pepper on the inviting nose of this bottling. There is a great range of flavor on the palate, from boysenberry juice to potpourri to roasted meat, and it all rides strong acid across the lightly tannic structure.
Wine: Bianchi 2015 Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This vineyard has the lowest production and gets the most (75%) new French oak. Black fruits abound, with generous streaks of cola and mocha. The tannins are substantial, the mouthfeel a bit grainy, and there's a pleasing, chewy toasty character to the finish.
Wine: Cristom 2016 Marjorie Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: Sophisticated, dry and well structured, this Bordeaux-style blend from winemaker Pam Starr is big and flavorful while achieving good balance, too. It has perfumed oak aromas, opulent black-cherry and blackberry flavors, lots of velvety tannins for grip and enough concentration for a lingering finish.
Wine: Crocker & Starr 2014 Bridesmaid Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black currant and smashed black plum meet with crushed slate and turned loam on the deep and dark nose of this blend of 81% Petite Sirah, 14% Tannat and 5% Tempranillo. Thick with grippy but smooth tannins, and wrapped in a buoyant acidity, the brawny blend offers the darkest and driest of fruit flavors.
Wine: Daou 2016 Unbound Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a very flavorful, medium- to full-bodied wine that blends ripe black cherry and clove with hints of vanilla and cinnamon. Supportive fruit acidity and light tannins add structure for an appetizing mouthfeel.
Wine: Davies 2016 Goorgian Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Richly fruity and lushly textured, this palate-coating Pinot offers a wealth of fruit flavors revolving around berry jam. Details of spice and nougat compound the finish, and a rather light touch of new French oak keeps everything in perfect proportion.
Wine: De Ponte Cellars 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: Like its bigger Mount Eden sister, this more affordable, usually more immediately accessible bottling needs time to open up. With patience, aromas of honeysuckle, oak and nuts provide a savory impression. The palate combines grapefruit pith and Meyer lemon rinds with savory salt and nuts.
Wine: Domaine Eden 2015 Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Review: This is the winery's only vineyard outside of the Dundee Hills AVA, and it stands out for its aromatic blend of Asian spices, backed with a hint of graphite. The fruit touches on a cherry cola flavor—not a criticism at all—and the wine continues through a finish with excellent depth and texture.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Abbey Oaks Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Review: This reserve white is tangled in tones of brioche and crème brûlée, with a bright shock of lively acidity that supports an underlying cradle of toasted oak. Stone, quince and a spark of lemon meringue add intrigue to the midpalate. Best 2020–2025.
Wine: Donum 2015 Year of the Ram Reserve Single Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Lovely aromas include a whiff of meat along with ripe berries, oranges and Bing cherries. This is the winery's most limited selection and saw the most new French oak, adding a pleasing toasty note to the finish. There's a suggestion of coffee grounds, and everything is already in good proportion. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Duck Pond 2016 Front Yard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 53% Syrah and 47% Grenache is well integrated on those nose with candied blackberry and lilac aromas. A chalky mouthfeel presents flavors of dark berry, cedar and slate on the palate, which is extremely well structured and should last for years. Drink now–2030.
Wine: Epiphany 2015 Revelation Rodney's Vineyard Red (Santa Barbara County)

Review: Stemmy and carbonic in nature, this wine exudes earthy forest, with bright, fresh up-front notes of strawberry, lemon and grapefruit peel. Light and on the precipice of ripeness, it dances that fine line well, offering up plenty of subtle flavor within a world of complexity.
Wine: Fera Mena 2015 Terra de Promissio Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: It's not entirely clear what this wine is a counterpoint too, although it certainly offsets the bigger richer wines that dominate Paso Robles. Bright aromas of grenadine, spicy hibiscus and cinnamon lead into a palate of juicy red cherry, pomegranate and rosewater. It's bright and refreshing.
Wine: Grace + Vine 2015 CounterPoint Lot 1 Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Both the white and the red Avni bottlings provide fine and accessible introductions to the Lingua Franca lineup. This has a creamy mouthfeel and strongly oaky/toasty aromas, yet remains poised and nicely detailed. Bright acidity supports fresh fruit flavors of crisp apple and white melon. It's drinking well currently and should continue to provide pleasure into 2025.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 Avni Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A faded shade of pink in the glass, this nonvintage bubbly offers rose petals, lemon, raspberry and chalk aromas. The palate starts with a sour strawberry and watermelon flavors, combining a strong tartness with recognizable and welcome fruit flavors.
Wine: Melville NV Blanc de Noir Non-Dosé Sparkling (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This stunning effort pays tribute to the Super Tuscan style, and it carries the weight of genuine experience. Co-owner/winemaker Scott Kelley worked several vintages in Montalcino on the Mondavi/Frescobaldi Luce/Lucente project. The blend here is 62% Sangiovese, 31% Merlot and 7% Syrah. The wine is both floral and fruity, still young and spicy. At first the barrel flavors seem a bit raw, but with decanting they smooth out and a pleasing black cherry and mocha flavor takes hold.
Wine: Paul O'Brien 2014 Il Rinnegati Red (Southern Oregon)

Review: Winemaker Pietro Buttita loves to tackle unusual grape varieties and he did a great job with this one. The wine is beautifully concentrated and focused, practically bursting at the seams with black-cherry and blackberry flavors that are extremely ripe and potent. It's so intense that the fruit notes cling to the tongue and sides of the mouth, echoing on the finish.
Wine: Prima Materia 2014 Aglianico

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this extremely well-priced bottling, named after vineyard manager Ruben Solorzano's wife, is intense yet elegant, with crushed slate, black currant and charred pork aromas. The palate's chalky texture carries flavors of black plum, boysenberry, dark cocoa, fennel and marjoram.
Wine: Stolpman 2017 Para Maria de los Tecolotes Red (Santa Barbara County)

Review: Chris Figgins' Oregon project hits the half decade mark with this lovely, stylish young wine. A plummy purple hue, it's lightly scented with toast, sandalwood and cedar. Silky smooth in the mouth, it's a bowl of ripe blueberries, done in an elegant style. There's the slightest suggestion of menthol as well. It's beautifully crafted and should be enjoyed over the next five to eight years.
Wine: Toil Oregon 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fashioned entirely from estate-grown grapes, this muscular and substantial wine melds together black cherry, black olive and sweet spices. It's firm and polished, with almost silky tannins, and punches well above its price. Drink this now through the next decade.
Wine: Trisaetum 2016 Willamette Valley Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Review: Here is a great discovery from often overlooked Madera County. There's a lot going on in this dark-colored, very aromatic and full-flavored wine that has matured for quite a while in the bottle already. Earthy, meaty, leathery aromas vie for attention while very potent fruit, dark-spice and beef jus flavors virtually flood the palate and cling to the sides of the mouth.
Wine: Westbrook Wine Farm 2012 Fait Accompli Red (Madera)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Wine:
#56
92
POINTS
Shannon Ridge 2016 High Elevation Collection Petite Sirah (Lake County)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 55% Grenache, 27% Syrah, 15% Mourvèdre, 2% Petite Sirah and 1% Carignan is a strong showing for this historic—but only recently revived—region between Morgan Hill and Gilroy. Blackberry, lavender, elderflower buds and soil show on the nose. The structure is quite firm, holding elegant flavors of dark berry, white pepper and strong acidity.
Wine: Aver Family Vineyards 2015 Hope Red (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Smooth and integrated, this is an earthy and spicy wine that offers balanced flavors of strawberry jam, citrus and a dash of white pepper. These tones linger as the wine's seamless, viscous texture takes hold.
Wine: Balletto 2016 Sexton Hill Vineyard Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fairly dark in the glass, this is an intense and jammy take on Pinot Noir, offering aromas of boysenberry and blackberry on the nose. It's brawny and masculine on the sip, with a full and creamy mouthfeel with just enough tang, and would work well in a steak house.
Wine: Challen 2015 Scarlett Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Each of the winery's Pinots showcases a specific AVA, and each is quite distinctive. Here, the sharply etched scents suggest raspberry jam and preserved lemon, and the following flavors retain that tight focus. Notes of blood orange and pineapple highlight the acidity, and the wine continues on with herbal notes. The tannins, still a bit stiff, will benefit from further bottle aging.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2016 Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Blackberry and chocolate are front and center, but this wine offers much more. It's creamy and lush on the palate, with mocha, toast and a touch of orange peel. The long, full finish brings in some black tea astringency.
Wine: Duck Pond 2016 St. Jory Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A beautiful shade of light purple in the glass, this first estate bottling off of this new property in the southwest corner of the appellation shows red currant, cherry and star anise on the nose. The palate starts with tangy black-raspberry fruit, but the focus is the compelling tannic tension and bright acid.
Wine: Folded Hills 2016 Estate Grenache (Santa Ynez Valley)

Review: Roasted berries, dark cocoa, white pepper and a touch of tar make for a compelling aromatic entry to this bottling from the new project owned by Andy Busch from the famous brewing family. It's firmly textured on the palate, offering flavors of black plum, lilac and a hint of charcoal.
Wine: Folded Hills 2016 Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Winemaker Ryan Huett labels this his “ultra” reserve—no doubt a reference to its single vineyard, single barrel origins. It's a mouthfilling explosion of black cherry cola, with pleasant, persistent highlights of tobacco, tea and lemon oil.
Wine: Huett 2016 Folie Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: Winemaker Katy Wilson crafts a delicate, grainy and textured wine from coastal fruit in this light-bodied, crisp and fresh take on the variety. Impressive on the midpalate in establishing just the right amount of weight to give it complexity and bite, it finishes in a seductive layer of clove and cola.
Wine: LaRue 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Toasty aromas of seared lemon, citrus pith and ashy Brie rind show on the nose of this bottling from the longtime grape-growing family. The palate is extremely focused and sharp, offering lime sorbet, green pear and more pithy qualities, wrapped in a compellingly grippy texture.
Wine: Melville 2015 Estate Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: A bit lighter in color, the aromas offer notes of earthy funk, blackberry, wet stone, blood and smoke—not quite seeming fully ready to reveal their charms on first pour. Fruit and savory flavors coat the palate, showing a sense of elegance, energy and freshness.
Wine: No Girls 2015 La Paciencia Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reliable vineyard delivers powerful brambly berry flavors in abundance. It's a big, textural, palate-filling wine, smooth and a bit tannic. There's a touch of green tea in those tannins, and it finishes with a hint of heat. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Purple Hands 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Noticeably cloudy in the glass, this single-vineyard exploration shows rich mulberry, black plum and candied rose-petal aromas. It's soft and creamy on the palate, where tart red plum and fresh thyme flavors prove a promising pairing.
Wine: Roar 2016 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from a majority of the variety blended with dozens of interplanted varieties that date back to the site's planting in 1890, this impresses in its lovely, lifted aromatics of nutmeg and clove. On the palate, expect blackberry cobbler and plum with an underbelly of balanced ripeness.
Wine: Rock Wall 2016 Alegria Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lemon syrup, toasty sandalwood, dried mango and nectarine show on the nose of this bottling from vines planted in 2007. The palate pairs squeezed lemon, guava and mango-cream flavors with a hint of oak and decent acid, finishing with a waxy texture.
Wine: Tantara 2016 Tondre Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Outcrop was planted in 1982, and these older vines make a wine with a distinctly Burgundian hue. This fits the classic Eyrie profile, tight and compact, with herbal aromas of peavine and rhubarb. Details of stem and leaf accompany tart raspberry fruit. This wine needs aggressive aeration if you plan to drink it soon; but it should age quite well. Drink 2025–2035.
Wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2015 Outcrop Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Named to honor a family member, these grapes were planted in 1989. As with all the Eyrie single vineyard Pinots, the aromas are complex and compelling. Flavors are light and detailed, with suggestions of leaf and compost under wild berries. This young wine will benefit from another couple of years of bottle aging; drink after 2020.
Wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2015 Roland Green Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Savory aromas of pepper, roast beef and hearty dark fruit show on the nose of this bottling, a rare Syrah from the Santa Lucia Highlands. There are tangy flavors of underripe blackberry on the palate, but the crushed peppercorn and lamb roast with rosemary elements are most prominent.
Wine: Waxwing 2015 Tondre Grapefield Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: Black plum, violet, lilac and a hint of chocolate are well integrated on the tangy yet rich nose of this balanced effort by a winery that recently changed hands. The wine hits the palate with hefty black-cherry, blackberry and elderberry-jam flavors, proving thick and impressive atop chalky tannins.
Wine: Westerly 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's an herbal kick on the nose of this single-vineyard expression, with dried seasonings and tea leaves lifting the boysenberry fruit core. More tea and marjoram meet with roasted plums on the palate, which is cut by crisp acidity.
Wine: Bernardus 2016 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: A herbal and perfumed nose opens this lovely, well-made and robust wine, which is both softly round and complex in nature. A billowy texture supports firm acidity, integrated oak and bursts of red and black fruit, plum and clove.
Wine: Chiron Wines 2015 Pelkan Ranch Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Knights Valley)

Review: Bright aromas of pomegranate, raspberry sorbet, ripe cherry, rosewater candy and vanilla show on the fresh yet luxurious nose of this bottling. It's light in feel, with a tense in structure that carries flavors of strawberry, cinnamon and dried ginger.
Wine: Croma Vera 2016 Grenache (Paso Robles)

Review: Simply lovely from first sniff to last sip, this wine offers a supple mix of ripe fruits—berries, plums and cherries. Time in one-quarter new French oak adds a touch of chocolate and softens up the tannins, resulting in an almost buttery mouthfeel.
Wine: De Ponte Cellars 2015 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: A rare blend of Dundee Hills Pinot Noir and Walla Walla Syrah, this belies the notion that Pinot is not a grape for such mash-ups. In this vintage the balance seems just right; neither grape dominates. Cassis and coffee flavors combine, with a touch of charred wood. There's a bit of heat in the finish, but a good steak will absorb the added oomph.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Grand Cheval Oregon Red Wine Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's lovely styling evident in this young wine, which seems delicately sculpted and boasts mouthfilling flavors. Plum, blueberry and brown spices are in the mix, with polished tannins that ensure a smooth glide through the lingering finish.
Wine: Elk Cove 2016 Five Mountain Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Clove and forest pine open this immensely perfumed and expressive vintage-designate, its backbone built in plush, polished tannin and lengthy power. Black cherry, brambly berry and cola complement each other in dense, concentrated waves.
Wine: Entrepreneur 2014 Widdoes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the family's 10-acre estate vineyard, this wine is defined by its balance: a sweet embrace of delicate red fruit complemented by earthy, savory dried herb and pine. Light, carbonic and exotic, it shows a grip of tannin that softens over time in the glass, reflective of a concentrated vintage.
Wine: Inman Family 2015 OGV Estate Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Boushey fruit makes up three-quarters of this wine with the balance being Elephant Mountain. Seeing just a kiss of new oak (12.5%), aromas of smoked meat, dried herb, earth, iron and dark blue fruit lead to bright, pure, fleshy fruit and savory flavors that bring a sense of seriousness. There's a compelling sense of freshness that heightens the appeal. A long finish caps it off.
Wine: Kevin White 2016 En Hommage Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Review: This is an up-and-coming variety in the Rocks District subregion of the valley. The aromas are generous, with notes of moist earth, tobacco, cherry and dried herb. The flavors are elegant in style, showing a sense of texture and grace. The finish kicks it up a notch.
Wine: No Girls 2015 Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Review: Cedar, pencil shavings and toasted oak accent a rich full-bodied core of red-cherry cola and berry in this mountain-grown wine that offers plenty of grip and acid-supported structure. The aromatics are perfumed and the length of the finish impressive in strong tannin.
Wine: Robert Biale 2016 Stagecoach Vineyard Zinfandel (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Illogical alchemy happens when Roussanne (25% in this case) is thrown in with dark grapes like Petite Sirah: the purple wine actually gets darker thanks to the white grape's oily grip. This well-named bottling shows black currant, Concord grape, blackberry juice and crushed lilacs on the deep and hearty nose, while the palate is driven by ripe and roasted black plums, finishing with hints of maple syrup, brown sugar and gingerbread spice.
Wine: Stolpman 2016 Hair of the Bear Red (Ballard Canyon)

Review: Complex, compelling aromas of fig, mint and cocoa start this full-bodied wine off with a bang before rich, jammy blackberry and blueberry flavors flood the palate. The texture is quite tannic, but is balanced out by the richness and concentration of the fruit tones. It's a big, boisterous wine that needs some equally big proteins to pair with. Best after 2020.
Wine: Two Angels 2016 Petite Sirah (Red Hills)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Excellent depth of fruit flavor makes this Cabernet Sauvignon-based blend a standout. There is little obvious oak flavor to detract from the very ripe, opulent black-cherry and blackberry flavors that soak through moderate tannins and fill the mouth with generous, layered richness. It has a fine structure for aging, too. Best through 2023.
Wine: Winery by the Creek 2015 Estate Grand Reserve Red (Fair Play)

Review: Pinpoint flavors compel your attention, with a mix of rhubarb, pomegranate and red berry. There's a sprinkle of oregano and well-managed highlights of coffee and toast from 10 months in one-quarter new French oak. This continues to be one of the finest values in a Willamette Valley Pinot Noir.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The name means meadow on the hill. This is a compelling mix of black raspberry fruit, savory meat stock and a touch of sour plum. Details of fresh herbs come up through the residual flavors, and the overall balance extends the enjoyment.
Wine: Bergström 2016 Le Pré du Col Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Review: Spicy, earthy and dark in fruit, this vineyard-designate offers integrated oak and a broad fleshy midpalate. Full-bodied richness and ripeness go hand in hand to make for a voluptuous expression of the grape from a tremendous site.
Wine: Black Kite 2016 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rich aromas of black currant, gingerbread, fresh lilac and jasmine slide into a meatier backbone on the nose of this bottling. It's soft on the palate at first and then spreads out to reveal blackberry, violet and roasted pork flavors, framed by solid acidity and fine tannins.
Wine: Brecon Estate 2016 Glenrose Vineyard Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is the original block at the estate vineyard, and the wine remains tight and a bit astringent at the moment. Wild berries, orange peel and a touch of meat stock all combine, with stiff, chewy tannins. It has all the hallmarks of a wine that needs another couple of years to pull itself together. It should drink well through the 2020s.
Wine: Cristom 2016 Louise Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: This puts a bit of emphasis on the herbal side of Oregon Pinot, without intruding on fresh, ripe raspberry fruit. There's a whiff of chicken stock, and notes of parsley and light baking spices. The wine spent 11 months in 40% new French oak.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2016 Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe red cherry meets with hints of dewy thyme, sagebrush and minty earth on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is loaded with herbal impact, as thyme and oregano provide depth to the pomegranate and raspberry flavors.
Wine: Foxen 2016 Julia's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Once again the Bella Vida rings the bell as the best of a fine lineup of Pinots from Fullerton. Rich, ripe, powerful fruit flavors mix strawberry jam, black cherry syrup, coffee, cola and brown spices. It's not a wine you have to wait on; enjoy it now through the early 2020s.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Bella Vida Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Blackberry aromas are layered with savory touches of pepper, salt, leather and turned earth on the complex and well-integrated nose of this Bordeaux blend, named for the Hearst family's rocky point off of San Simeon beach. Dark-red and black plums are lifted by marjoram and Asian spice on the medium-bodied palate.
Wine: Hearst Ranch 2015 The Point Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This is made from 80% Pinot Noir, the remainder Chardonnay, both coming from both the Napa and Sonoma sides of the appellation. Inviting in wild strawberry, it is dry and stony and exuberant in earthy mineral aspects of crushed rock and dried herb.
Wine: JCB 2014 No 34 Brut Rosé Sparkling (Carneros)

Review: From a cool site set on sedimentary and volcanic soils, this sets a sleek, supple tone throughout the palate. It deftly mixes in strata of earth and herb under black cherry fruit. Tannins are polished and firm. It's drinking well already, but seems likely to improve further with additional bottle aging.
Wine: Trisaetum 2016 Coast Range Estate Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Review: This is a really well-made, flavorful and nicely balanced wine from a new winery that's doing exciting things. It's full bodied, moderately tannic and moderately acidic which is typical of the varietal, but backed by wonderful ripe black-cherry, black-olive and black-pepper flavors.
Wine: Via Romano 2015 Barbera (El Dorado County)

Review: A pale shade of pink in the glass, this Grenache-based rosé is excellent, starting with soft aromas of bubblegum and pink lemonade. The palate is zesty, fresh and framed by persistent acid, with tangy raspberry, plum-skin and tight pomegranate flavors captured in a taut texture.
Wine: Wolff 2017 Rosé (Central Coast)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blends 70% Syrah and 30% Grenache from the estate site. The wine is bright and fresh on the nose, a whiff of peppery meat and earthy leather arriving first. The midplate takes on more ripe concentration in brambly blackberry and strawberry.
Wine: Ampelos 2015 Ampelos Vineyard Syrache Syrah-Grenache (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This supple, sexy wine is ready, set, go for immediate enjoyment. Pretty cherry and chocolate flavors round out the middle, with sweet spices all the way through a most pleasurable finish. All Pommard clone, it was aged 18 months in 30% new French oak.
Wine: Beacon Hill 2016 La Sierra Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: From what the producer considers its best pocket of vineyard, planted to multiple clones, this is a beautifully expressive wine, well-integrated and delicately layered, with a flowing, silky texture. The flavors delve into raspberry, strawberry and black tea, humming along to an earthy finish.
Wine: Belden Barns 2016 Serendipity Block Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)

Review: Think cherry pie fruit with a touch of pastry crust and you've got a handle on this tasty wine. The acids add citrus highlights, principally pineapple, and the tannins have a hint of green tea astringency.
Wine: Bergström 2016 Gregory Ranch Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe but sour cherry aromas meet with purple flowers, hibiscus, subtle chaparral and a hint of juniper on the nose of this bottling. It's energetic on the palate, with earthy clay flavors playing against the background of rhubarb, red plums and orange rinds.
Wine: Bernardus 2016 Garys' Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: With a touch of spice from well-integrated oak, this is a fresh and fruity white from a remarkable vineyard site, one of the best in the appellation. It shows balance within a context of undeniable ripeness and grip, the flavor defined in baked apple, almond and cinnamon.
Wine: Bouchaine 2016 Hyde Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Review: This is a great value for a wine of such quality, made with a handful of Petite Sirah that grows in the same field-blended site. Layered and grippy, it shows structured blackberry and mocha flavors around secondary tones of leather and earth.
Wine: Buehler 2015 Zinfandel (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Cristom's multivineyard blend is a polished effort that overdelivers for the price. Spicy and pungently herbal aromas lead into flavors of tart strawberry and peppery herb. The leaf and bark aspect is forceful but nicely integrated, and the structure suggests aging this a few years for optimal drinking.
Wine: Cristom 2016 Mount Jefferson Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: An opulent nose of ripe yellow apple and melon melds with highlights of rose, ginger and white pepper spice. The palate is rich and silken in feel yet impeccably balanced by supportive acidity and delicate astringency. Succulent flavors of melon and canned peach meet with flecks of spice and flowers to give an overall broad impression.
Wine: Damiani 2016 Barrel Fermented Gewürztraminer (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The winery's lineup of single vineyard Pinots features sites rarely if ever seen elsewhere, but all are deserving of extra attention. The high elevation (aptly named) Hylo Vineyard selection is all Pommard clone, with generous raspberry and cherry lollipop fruit. The natural-tasting acids bring citrus and tangerine, and the finish is focused and long.
Wine: Duck Pond 2016 Hylo Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very earthy on the front end, this clonal selection presents aromas of dark hibiscus, baked red fruits, pine forest floor, peppercorn and wild herbs. Tangy cranberry and sour cherry show on the sip, where a decent tension frames the palate.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Pommard Clone Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fresh and lively aromas of hibiscus, sumac and tea leaves make for a compelling entry to this bottling. Tart cherry and plum-skin flavors lead into richer fruit toward the finish, with touches of Earl Grey tea and loamy soil throughout.
Wine: Kessler-Haak 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Firmly rooted in flavors of blueberries and plums, this adds accents of black olive and green tea. The tannins are substantial and somewhat astringent, with a finishing touch of orange peel.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 The Plow Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Softly alluring and youthfully vibrant in fresh power and tart acidity, this block-designate is spicy and fruit-forward in black cherry, blackberry and a dip of vanilla cola.
Wine: MacMurray Estate Vineyards 2016 Winemaker's Block Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: Herbal and forested in savory elements like rose petal and black tea, this is a gorgeously rich and round red wine, a true showcase of the appellation and sure to please a crowd. Red and black cherry are met by wild strawberry and lush waves of depth.
Wine: Merry Edwards 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a beautiful, elegant, lighter-styled wine in a half-bottle that shows great balance between ripeness and fresh acidity. Lemon and crisp apple aromas lead to light vanilla and butter flavors that mingle well with the fruit elements.
Wine: Navarro 2016 Premiere Reserve Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 64% Grenache, 22% Mourvèdre and 14% Syrah certainly plays toward the riper end of the spectrum, but its roasted red fruit is deeply layered with star anise, ginger, clove and caramel aromas. It's powerful on the palate, with unctuous flavors of roasted blackberry and plum as well as more baking spice.
Wine: Oso Libre 2013 Carnal Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Blueberries and currants come with a lemony edge in this aromatic, rather delicate wine. Refined highlights add citrus rind, and as it breathes there's a nice cherry component also.
Wine: Purple Hands 2016 Kropf Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: This is a bright and lightly layered wine that offers tones of Asian spice, earth and black tea. The acidity is tart and tenacious, interwoven between gentle jolts of mint, chocolate and dark cherry.
Wine: Sean W. McBride 2016 Gremlin Vineyard Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This block selection is 100% Wadenswil clone, 13% whole cluster fermented, and aged in 50% new French oak. Strawberry and blueberry fruit plays out broadly across the palate, with notes of root beer and cola. It's open and forward, quite tasty, though not as dense or complex as some of Shea's other selections.
Wine: Shea 2016 Shea Vineyard Block 7 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Elegantly layered aromas of rose petal potpourri, cranberry, raspberry and sandalwood arise on the nose of this single-vineyard study. Creamy and soft with well-integrated acid on the palate, this wine offers flavors of plum and mulberry, making for a smooth sip.
Wine: Siduri 2016 Sierra Mar Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Heaping amounts of black pepper and raw meat aromas are followed by pillowy soft dark fruit and savory flavors that remain light on their feet, stretching out on the finish. It's a compelling offering of the variety.
Wine: Upsidedown 2016 The Gold Drop Collection Kitzke Vineyards Mourvèdre (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This block selection shines in 2016, sneaking up on the taster with flavors that build concentration through the finish. Black cherry, chocolate and a hint of mint all combine, and the overall balance argues for further bottle aging before popping the cork. Drink from 2022 on through the decade.
Wine: Alexana 2016 West Blocks-Sedimentary Soils Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This estate-grown bottling is ripe and juicy, with a luscious mix of orange and grapefruit flavors, along with a generous slice of melon. The mouthfeel is lightly creamy, and there's a suggestion of some residual sugar, though it is not specifically indicated.
Wine: Alexana 2017 Revana Vineyard Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is part of the winery's Terroir Series, but oddly, no specific terroir other than the generic Willamette Valley AVA is indicated. The flavors are leesy and balanced among fruit highlights of citrus, lime and papaya, with a strong minerality. Precise and stylish, it's already drinking quite well and should hold through 2023.
Wine: Alexana 2017 Terroir Series Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This aromatic young wine brings a mix of cherries and figs, with highlights of hazelnuts. Aged 10 months in one-sixth new French oak, it lightly suggests Snickers bars and malted milk ball candies, without overdoing either. Overall it's refined and well balanced, and should be consumed now–2025.
Wine: Anne Amie 2016 Winemaker's Selection Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Review: Light cranberry and strawberry flavors show impressive depth and breadth in this full-bodied expressive wine. Cola and cinnamon provide spicy seasoning that melds well with the fruit, the entirety textured in layers of velvety softness.
Wine: Cuvaison 2016 Mariafeld Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)

Review: As Devona wines are still produced in Walla Walla, these single vineyard efforts bear only the generic Oregon AVA on the label. This Elk Cove vineyard is now part of Devona's single vineyard lineup. Principally Pommard clone, it spent time in 30% new French oak, adding scents of toast and cigar box to the mix. The cherry fruit also has a tobacco flavor component, and the firm, smooth tannins finish with a touch of black tea.
Wine: Devona 2015 Mount Richmond Vineyard Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Review: This estate white is full of crushed rock and wet stone elements that blend with tones of apple, oak and salt. Light bodied and restrained, it shows a wealth of structure and aging potential. Enjoy 2020–2025.
Wine: Donum 2015 Year of the Ram Single Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark cherry and boysenberry aromas meet with a hint of anise on the nose of this bottling from Paso Robles' Westside. Flavors of strawberry compote and boysenberry paste are lifted by clove and gingerbread on the rich palate.
Wine: Dunning Vineyards 2015 Reserve Grenache (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light aromas of black raspberry, cranberry jam and a hint of oak smoke kick off the nose in this study of a popular clone. The smoky elements mask the fruit at first on the sip, but ripe berries and mulberry slowly arise alongside the charred pork flavors, bolstered by a long-simmering acidity.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Clone 115 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Lighter in the glass, this appellation blend shows pomegranate sorbet, cranberry skins, rose petals and wild herbs on the nose. The palate is crisp and tart with raspberry fruit that's lifted by chaparral spice and wild thyme.
Wine: Foxen 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: Candied aromas of ripe cherry meet with dark wild herbs and a hint of cedar on the nose of this bottling from a secret dream team of regional vintners. The wood element shows on the sip, where flavors of red plum and mulberry are lifted with fennel frond and herbal spices.
Wine: Grace + Vine 2014 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Review: A grip of reduction on the nose in tones of flint and matchstick is consistent for the producer's style. On the palate are light-bodied layers of green olive, pineapple, peach and lemon, a contrasting set of fruit and savory elements that work seamlessly together.
Wine: Grgich Hills 2016 Fumé Blanc Estate Grown Dry Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: Earthy, seductive and soft, this well-made wine offers tones of forest floor, pomegranate and strawberry. It delivers plenty of flavor beneath a delicately crafted body.
Wine: J Vineyards & Winery 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: Firmly anchored in black fruits, this is the current release (mid-2018). Details include black olive and coffee grounds, lightly applied, and the wine shows impressive depth and flavor persistence. It's truly a reserve-level Pinot at an entry-level price.
Wine: J. Wright 2014 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Review: Firm and precise, this pushes tart cranberry/raspberry fruit up front, with a seam of citrus oil and rind. Grapefruit highlights and lemony acidity flow into a lingering finish, with a comet's tail of chocolate.
Wine: J Wrigley 2016 828 Single Clone Estate Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Review: Succulent and bright, this interweaves crunchy red fruit into a cohesive whole of balanced freshness and high-acid tenacity, the tannins supportive in providing weight and grip.
Wine: LaRue 2014 Rice-Spivak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Mimi Casteel tends this vineyard, and this young, still-unevolved wine needs more time to fully blossom. It hews closely to the emerging Lingua Franca style—not quite austere, but focused, tart and juicy, with just-ripe-enough flavors of cranberry and raspberry front and center. This should continue to improve over the next eight to 10 years, so tuck it away until 2020.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 Hope Well Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This robust and fragrant Cabernet is bolstered by 6% Malbec. It's a potent wine that displays rich flavors of black fruits, coffee and cacao. The tannins resolve on the finish, with a drying sensation of black tea.
Wine: Lük 2016 Serra Vineyard Own Rooted Cabernet Sauvignon (Applegate Valley)

Review: This winery is the project of second generation Beaux Frères founders Jared Etzel and Marc-André Roy. Aromatic and well integrated, this cuvée has fruit flavors of tart strawberry preserves, underscored with streaks of earth, herb and cola. The tannins are ripe enough, though still a bit chewy. A couple of more years of bottle aging is recommended.
Wine: Maison Roy 2015 Incline Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Review: This Santa Cruz Mountains-based winery has been making a value-driven Edna Valley Chardonnay since 1985, and this one does not disappoint, Pungent aromas of lemon oil and orange pith are rounded by seared white peach, crushed sand and smoke on the nose, while the zesty palate delivers more stone fruit, bright lemon, toasty oak and solid tannic tension.
Wine: Mount Eden Vineyards 2016 Chardonnay (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Shy at first on the nose, this wine begins to show pithy aromas of tangerine alongside gardenia and a touch of sour cream. The palate is texturally driven with grippy tension that leads into more orange-pith and pink-grapefruit flavors, finishing on an ashy Brie-rind quality.
Wine: Soquel Vineyards 2017 Lone Oak Vineyard Partners' Reserve Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A blend of fruit from Boushey, Olsen and Sagemoor vineyards. The aromas pop, with appealing notes of raspberry, smoked meat, herb, white pepper, potpourri and mountain blueberry. Textured, swoon-worthy blue fruit and savory flavors follow and persist through the lingering finish. It's a thoroughly captivating wine, with a lovely sense of freshness.
Wine: Sparkman 2016 Wonderland Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Review: Leonetti Cellar/Figgins/Toil winemaker Chris Figgins jumps into Chardonnay for the first time with grapes from McMinnville's Dupee vineyard. Juicy fruit flavors of pear and peach, along with a light touch (20%) of new oak, make for a full, firm, well-balanced young wine with years of life ahead.
Wine: Toil Oregon 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Matthew Driscoll's wines hit a consistently high standard, and this young Pinot Blanc deftly mixes several emerging trends in Oregon: whole cluster pressing, native yeasts and light exposure to all- (or mostly) neutral oak. Apple, peach and pear flavors come with a touch of cinnamon, and the sur lie aging adds a crunchy/creamy texture throughout.
Wine: WildAire 2017 Stater Vineyard Pinot Blanc (Dundee Hills)

Review: Abacela's reds are dark, bold and tannic, but the estate-grown fruit is up to the challenge of the extended barrel aging. Bourbon tea aromas introduce this pure Malbec, which does a vertical dive into deep black cherry and cassis fruit. A spine of iron and finishing touches of licorice and espresso contribute to a powerful, tannic finish.
Wine: Abacela 2015 Malbec (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fermented in neutral oak, this retains lovely floral aromas and flavor notes of roses and orange blossoms. They introduce a robust mix of peach, apricot and cantaloupe fruit. The lingering finish may call to mind the last lick of an orange creamsicle.
Wine: Alexana 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Review: This is a well-integrated white wine, made in an unabashedly full-bodied manner that displays ample fruit. Fig, vanilla and a thread of lemon zest give it plenty of flavor and crowd-pleasing personality.
Wine: Black Stallion 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Review: This white is rich and creamy, with a slight note of reduction. Decadent in caramel toffee and crème brûlée, it is well made and succulent, allowing the fruit to shine over the well-integrated oak.
Wine: Bouchaine 2016 Chêne d'Argent Estate Chardonnay (Carneros)

Review: This wine offers a deep inviting nose of blackberry cobbler, lavender and violet, the fruit dense and concentrated. There's a lift of freshness on the finish that keeps it alive and balanced in the glass.
Wine: Burt Street Cellars 2014 Herman Vineyard Syrah (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is an excellent year for this east-facing block, with bright blackberry and cherry fruit anchored in firm tannins. There's a scent and flavor of chicken stock. Half was whole cluster fermented, and the wine spent 18 months in three-fifths new French oak.
Wine: Cristom 2016 Jessie Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Review: From fruit grown at both Cuvaison and Hyde vineyards, this is a celebration of the appellation, with pleasing, earthy cardamom and a touch of mint. Dark cherry, vanilla and orange flavors layer around moderate oak and acidity, forming a fruit-friendly complex whole.
Wine: Davies 2016 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Review: Amid big changes at this winery (Drew Voit was recently named as the winemaker), this new release is closest to the style for which it has become known. It's an elegant, delightful wine, detailed with fine streaks of cola, cherry, sassafras and baking spices. There's the slightest whiff of chili pepper also. And the finish, integrated with supple tannins, carries another light hint, this one of leather. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Elizabeth Chambers 2015 Menefee Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This vineyard designate is all 777 clone, fermented in rotator barrels and aged in neutral French oak. It follows a consistent style with the winery's other releases, a palate-pleasing mix of Bing cherry, cola, brown spices and a touch of cut tobacco.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Lichtenwalter Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 64% Upland and Boushey Grenache along with 27% Sugarloaf Mourvèdre and 9% Boushey Syrah, all aged in neutral oak. The aromas are knee buckling, with notes of huckleberry, black raspberry, leather, black pepper, stargazer lily, kirsch and orange peel, showing an outrageous sense of purity. The palate bursts with soft black pepper, smoked meat and red and blue fruit flavors that persist on the finish. It's all about purity, but there's a sense of freshness as well that is thoroughly captivating.
Wine: Kevin White 2016 La Fraternite Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Here is an outstanding everyday Chardonnay, both affordable and flavorful. Rich fruit flavors combine melon and peach with a touch of grapefruit. Primarily fermented in stainless steel, but a light hint of oak from a small portion that has been barrel-fermented adds a toasty note to the finish.
Wine: Lange 2017 Classique Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Review: Aromas of black pepper and wood smoke meld with rich, concentrated and jammy fruit flavors in this full-bodied, firmly tannic and impressive wine. Aged in 50% new barrels from France and Hungary, It shows plenty of spicy, almost sweet oak character to offset the dense flavors and big structure. Best after 2023.
Wine: McKahn 2016 Petite Sirah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied violets, black currant candy, lilac and even a hint of jasmine show on the floral nose of this blend of 35% Cabernet Sauvignon, 35% Merlot, 17% Petit Verdot, 8% Malbec and 5% Cabernet Franc. Bright flavors of dark-purple fruit are leveled by a chalky mouthfeel, solid structure and ample acid.
Wine: Midnight 2014 Mare Nectaris Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Review: This blends 36% Syrah, 23% Mourvèdre, 22% Viognier and 19% Grenache. A beautiful perfume of violet opens the proceedings, followed by white pepper, garrigue, lavender and meat. A high-toned midpalate tames the wine's richer, riper leanings that takes on a robust taste of strawberry leather before pepper comes back to dot the finish.
Wine: Novy 2015 G-S-M (Sonoma Valley)

Review: Brown sugar, red berry, lavender and a touch of heat mark this velvety thick and smoothly tannic wine, a hearty showcase of the variety. Complex and interwoven in oak, it finishes in bits of black and white pepper.
Wine: Robert Biale 2016 Royal Punishers Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)

Review: This is a delicious and substantial wine that emphasizes subtlety and structure, while slowly revealing fruity, spicy and savory elements with each sip. It has reserved pear and almond aromas that carry to a palate accented by ripe peach, vanilla and cream. The texture is viscous and holds everything together.
Wine: Sketchbook 2017 Chardonnay (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a lightly minty, fruity and forward wine of medium concentration. Aging in 30% new French oak brings up sweet baking spices around blueberry and cherry fruit. Drinking well already, it should improve through 2024.
Wine: Stoller 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: Exotic in aroma and grainy in texture, this tiny-production wine excites in its thick layers of crisp and crunchy tang of fruit, which spans from pomegranate to wild strawberry to boysenberry. Layers of cola add a richness that trails on the finish.
Wine: Talisman 2014 Adastra Vineyard Méthode Ancienne Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)

Review: Touches of dried herbs and black olives in the aromas and flavors give an authentic appeal to this full-flavored and full-bodied wine. A hint of spicy oak enhances the experience but doesn't overwhelm the fruity, savory aspects that are so enjoyable.
Wine: Viaggio 2014 The President Merlot (Lodi)

Review: This bottling from the extremely coastal Jespersen Ranch shows what a truly cool climate can do for Sauvignon Blanc. It's tightly woven but approachable on the nose, with aromas of honeydew, kiwi and wet stone. The palate is incredibly zippy, offering chalky flavors of apple and pear. A lime rind tartness holds the finish.
Wine: Niner 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Edna Valley)

Review: From an estate-grown site that's rocky and sheltered from high heat, this wine, blended with 4% Malbec, retains plenty of firm acidity alongside big-boned tannins and balanced weight. Coffee and cassis complement a wealth of dark cherry, blueberry and plum flavors.
Wine: Acumen 2014 Peak Attelas Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Review: Dark berry and cherry fruits meet with turned earth, oak smoke and wet rocks on the intriguing nose of this bottling from the Santa Maria community college winery. Boysenberry and black-raspberry flavors show on the sip alongside shaved cocoa and soil flavors, the overall richness cut smartly by acid.
Wine: Allan Hancock 2016 Malbec (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Bright and balanced, this is from a relatively warm site and is full, fleshy and meaty in style. Savory black tea and cardamom season a core of red cassis, black cherry and strawberry, with a soft, velvety texture behind the fruit.
Wine: Balletto 2016 BCD Vineyard Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The West block vines date to 1977 and reveal complex flavors of pomegranate and raspberry fruit, layered with chocolate and coconut streaks. It's balanced and persistent, drinking nicely and set to age gracefully for a decade or longer.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2016 West Block Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve-level wine, from the estate's Ribbon Ridge AVA vineyard, is concentrated and complicated. Aging in half new oak barrels piles on flavors of baking spices and toast, while the core of ripe cherry fruit is highlighted with streaks of cola, coffee and tobacco. It's drinking quite nicely and should continue to do so through 2025.
Wine: Chehalem 2015 Ridgecrest Vineyards (Reserve) Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Review: The talented Herb Quady had a hand in making this wine, a delicious bottle jam-packed with flavors of blueberry compote and blueberry cobbler. It's tasty, forward and set in a palate-pleasing toasty frame. Drink now–2023.
Wine: Deer Creek 2015 Private Reserve Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: Huge in tannin structure, this mountain-grown wine includes 7% Carignan and 2% Zinfandel. Baked bread, red fruit, leather and sizable brawn characterize its youthfulness; enjoy best 2025–2030.
Wine: Elyse 2015 York Creek Vineyard Petite Sirah (Spring Mountain District)

Review: This mix of clone 115 and Pommard is principally sourced for vines more than three decades old. It's firmly anchored in dark flavors of black cherry, cassis, baker's chocolate and espresso. Tannins are ripe and firm, while the finish carries a light suggestion of charred wood.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Fir Crest Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Clean, crisp and reminiscent of springtime on the nose, this bottling shows aromas of lime blossom, wet cement, scratched pomelo skin and cut grass. The palate is extremely energetic and makes the mouth tingle while delivering flavors of lemongrass and lime.
Wine: Gainey 2017 Limited Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A tad lighter in style than the winery's richer bottlings, this fresh wine shows pomegranate, dried roses and a hint of game on the nose. Freshly squeezed black-raspberry and sour cherry flavors ride a sharp acidity into the finish.
Wine: Kessler-Haak 2015 Ohana Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted black currants, charred meats, purple flowers, milk chocolate and a hint of teriyaki show on the nose of this layered and complex bottling from vintner Don Lorenzi. There is a strong structure to the palate, where anise and wild herbs show against a core of black plum pudding.
Wine: Lorenzi Estate 2014 Private Reserve Estate Grown Petite Sirah (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Earthy and reserved at first on the nose, this new reserve bottling from the popular label offers rhubarb pie, turned earth and purple flower potpourri on the nose. Ripe fruit flavors of cranberry and raspberry show on the palate, as do turned earth and crushed slate flavors—a more elegant step up from the original bottling.
Wine: Meiomi 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This chewy, flavorful wine features well-ripened black cherry fruit and a dark streak of chocolate. Barrel aging (half new) adds toasted nuts to the mix, and the finish is focused and lingers gracefully, balanced with clean acids.
Wine: Panther Creek 2016 De Ponte Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A blend of one-third Schindler and two-thirds Lazy River fruit, this reserve was aged for 17 months in two-thirds new French oak. Unsurprisingly, it's a toasty wine, with fruit solidly in the black cherry camp, and streaks of smoke, tar and chocolate.
Wine: Panther Creek 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Clean, brambly fruit emphasizes red fruit flavors, with highlights of coffee and chocolate. It's a textural wine, medium bodied and perfect for drinking now and over the next half decade.
Wine: Purple Hands 2016 Holstein Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Review: From the cooler edge of the Petaluma Gap, this is coharvested and cofermented with 10% Viognier, which gives it a lift on the midpalate. Smoky char, baked raspberry, leather and pepper highlight a complex, thickly concentrated experience of powerful grace and silky texture.
Wine: Ramey 2014 Rodgers Creek Vineyard Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Produced from Hartzinger Vineyard Pinot Noir, this potent bubbly spent three years en tirage. It's a sunset copper color, with tangy strawberry and cherry flavors. Bubbles are compact, and the wine has the requisite acidity, finishing with a refreshing burst of minerality.
Wine: Raptor Ridge 2014 Sparkling Brut Rosé Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hay yellow in the glass, this vibrant bubbly, made from Chardonnay, offers aromas of toast and shaved nectarine on the nose. The palate is loaded with lemon flavors, proving tangy, tart and pleasantly sour as it rides across the creamy mousse.
Wine: Riverbench 2015 Cork Jumper Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Santa Maria Valley)

Review: An extended barrel-aged red, given 30 months to settle in French oak, this wine remains thick and chewy on the palate, a fistful of red raspberry and blackberry finding supportive acidity to boost the fruit. Bark, oak and graham cracker characteristics add richness and complexity. Enjoy best 2025 through 2030.
Wine: Robert Biale 2015 EBA Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)

Review: Smooth and velvety with a taste of black pepper, leather, fig and gravel, this wine integrates its tannin and oak well, allowing room for complexity and freshness to flourish. It has aspects of violet and lavender and a richness on the finish that speaks to blackberry jam.
Wine: Robert Biale 2015 Like Father, Like Son Syrah-Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Red-cherry compote, star anise, red licorice and a hint of vanilla show on the nose of this bottling from one of Adam Lee's longtime sources in the region. The palate offers rusty and earth flavors of baked cherry, but is quite snappy and crisp, enhanced by oregano, pepper and dried flowers.
Wine: Siduri 2016 Clos Pepe Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a lovely, structured blend half Cabernet Sauvignon with 17% Petit Verdot, 15% Malbec, 14% Cabernet Franc and 4% Merlot, from the mountainous estate. Opening in a sweet nose of sage and vanilla, it's savory in red currant and cassis, with grippy tannins. Enjoy best from 2024–2030.
Wine: Spring Mountain Vineyard 2014 Elivette Red (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Soft, light and grippy on the midpalate in toasted oak and firm tannin, this is moderately structured and fully ripe, brimming in black cherry, cola and clove.
Wine: Talisman 2014 Gunsalus Vineyard Dijon Clone 114 Méthode Ancienne Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: Anthesis (not antithesis!) is produced and marketed by Blue Apron, one of several online start-ups offering home delivered fresh foods. This vineyard-designated, organically grown wine is a genuinely substantial effort. Black cherry and raspberry jam push flavors forward, while firm tannins and a touch of black olive keep the finish textural and lingering. It's packaged in a 500 ml bottle, perfect with that dinner for two.
Wine: Anthesis 2016 Stermer & Briscoe Vineyards Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The first of the winery's 2016s, this young wine shows tart pomegranate and white raspberry fruits, with a hint of watermelon, as one might find in a rosé. Fermented in a mix of oak, concrete and stainless steel, the resulting blend is lighter than the previous vintage, with a well-balanced, savory finish.
Wine: Archery Summit 2016 Dundee Hills Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from the Knudsen vineyard, this medium-bodied effort brings flavors of brambly berries and a touch of wet stone. It seems to trail off a bit in the finish, leaving a light lick of citrus as it fades.
Wine: Argyle 2016 Spirithouse Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Bold in flavor and stiff in structure, this full-bodied wine is laced with strong tannins and will need rich, fatty food to pair with. Still, it reveals nicely concentrated blueberry and blackberry flavors, subdued oak accents and a well-concentrated and layered composition.
Wine: Atrea 2016 Old Soul Red (Mendocino County)

Review: This is a great value for 100% varietal, cool-climate Syrah, a super earthy funky experience of confounding dried herb, lavender and grilled meat. Thick shocks of white pepper hedonistically dot the landscape.
Wine: Baker Lane 2015 Sonoma Coast Cuvée Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lighter aromas of pomegranate-based fruit punch and raspberry jam met with wild herbs on the nose of this bottling by the Carmel Valley-based producer. The punchy, fruit-forward flavors are easy to enjoy on the sip, although remain a tad simple and juicy.
Wine: Bernardus 2016 Sierra Mar Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Review: Named for estate owner Charlie's mother, this is an intense and powerful white, fiercely strong in acidity and lingering layers of Gravenstein apple and a squeeze of lemon. The lasting finish of integrated oak takes on a characteristic of hazelnut that's hugely pleasing.
Wine: Charles Heintz 2015 Rachael Estate Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As with the winery's other block selections, this is labeled Willamette Valley, but is composed entirely of estate-grown McMinnville AVA fruit. Brambly blackberries and well-delineated baking spices are amplified with floral aromas. Lilacs and cherries are here in abundance and are quite delightful.
Wine: Coeur de Terre 2015 Abby's Block Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a thick red wine, spicy in acidity and lengthy in waves of dark cherry, blackberry and cola. Full bodied and lush on the palate, it shows the strength of the appellation, site and vintage with ease.
Wine: Entrepreneur 2015 Widdoes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tart in rhubarb and strawberry and bushels of dried herb, this is a light-bodied delicate wine, restrained and balanced in ripeness and tone. The oak is well integrated and supportive.
Wine: Joseph Jewell 2015 Hallberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark red and purple fruits meet with caramelized and brown-sugar touches on the rich and lovely nose of this bottling. The palate is more tart than expected, with black-plum-skin flavors, and a dusting of white pepper, all framed in a firm dry structure.
Wine: Kessler-Haak 2015 Estate Grown Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Broad aromas of strawberry and peach flesh are cut my lime pith on the nose of this sparkling wine. Full raspberry and cherry-juice flavors on the palate are cut by a strong streak of sour and tart citrus spray, offering a balanced bubbly sip.
Wine: Kessler-Haak 2015 Rosé Sparkling (Sta. Rita Hills)

Review: Creamy and lush in texture, this boldly ripe white flirts with tropical flavors of pineapple, guava and mango. Its full-bodied complexity is additionally marked by exotic elements of anise and fig.
Wine: Knights Bridge 2016 West Block Chardonnay (Knights Valley)

Review: A distinctive and powerful fruitiness that's as rich as blackberry jam without being actually sweet gives this medium-bodied wine a big personality. Hints of spearmint and blueberry join the fun, and there is very little tannin or oakiness to get in the way.
Wine: LangeTwins 2015 Red Tail Vineyard Nero d'Avola (Lodi)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine is saturated with dark fruit and dark chocolate flavors while complex aromas of toasted oak, damp earth and new leather add to the enjoyment. It feels solid and firmly tannic, but velvety in texture. Best now–2025.
Wine: Langman Estate 2015 Raymond's Rows Petite Sirah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This nicely captures the toasty, lip-smacking power of vintage Champagne, hitting the palate immediately with an impression of both power and finesse. Youthful still, it offers tart fla-vors of lemon rind, pineapple and grapefruit. Though all stainless-steel fermentation and aging is indicated, that pleasing toasty note continues on through the finish.
Wine: Left Coast 2012 Blanc de Noir Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Both the white and the red Avni bottlings provide fine and accessible introductions to the Lingua Franca lineup. This well-crafted example mixes medium-bodied blue fruits and supporting, citrus-infused acidity. It's not a big wine, but is on point throughout a focused finish.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 Avni Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Velvety and full bodied, this is a robust, ripe wine, high-toned in notes of rhubarb, black tea and turned earth. It presents as lush and persistent on the palate, with a fruit-forward flavor and an impressive underlying complexity.
Wine: MacMurray Estate Vineyards 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Review: This admittedly huge wine offers tamed tannins, with a generous dose of spicy oak and a hint of sweetness that seem to absorb some of the astringency. It comes off as very concentrated and flavorful, showing an almost velvety texture.
Wine: Michael David 2016 Petite Petit Petite Sirah (Lodi)

Review: This barrel-fermented wine from an Anderson Valley institution has very nice balance, lots of juicy, fresh and ripe apple and peach flavors and a lightly tangy texture due to good acidity. It's medium bodied, easy to sip and will please a lot of different palates.
Wine: Navarro 2016 Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Review: This California producer jumps into Southern Oregon with a bright, spicy bottle of Pinot Noir, blending grapes from the Wooldridge Creek Vineyard and the Rock'N R Ranch. Big, broad flavors of cranberry, pineapple, vanilla and toast deliver plenty of pleasure. Drink while it retains its freshness, now–2020.
Wine: Omen 2017 Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)

Review: An outstanding value, this is the second label from Tempranillo specialist Paul O'Brien. It offers a boatload of mixed flavors and accents, with citrus, fig, cherry tobacco and bourbon tea all well represented and supported with lively acidity.
Wine: Oregon Territory 2015 Tempranillo (Oregon)

Review: Generous tannins present as chalky and grippy in this wine, which offers an herbal wrapping of cedar, graphite and red currant. Boldly flavored and built, it's substantial on the palate.
Wine: Paraduxx 2014 X2 Estate Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of pencil shavings, black peppercorn, oregano and elderberry frame the nose of this blend of 32% Merlot, 28% Cabernet Sauvignon, 18% Petit Verdot, 12% Cabernet Franc and 10% Malbec. It's tightly wound on the palate, where a dried cherry flavor meets with dried herbs and cracked pepper, lifted by a dash of acidity.
Wine: Rancho Sisquoc 2015 Cellar Select Meritage (Santa Barbara County)

Review: This is the estate vineyard bottling from Maison Jadot's Oregon project. As 2018 will mark the first vintage made in the new Résonance winery, it's not surprising that some variation will be found in previous vintages, which were made in a borrowed facility. The 2015 is sharp and peppery, with dark fruits, supple acids and hints of char and smoke. The tannins, at first a bit gritty, smooth out with some hours of breathing time. Best drinking window here may be 2020–2025.
Wine: Résonance 2015 Résonance Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Review: This is a tiny production wine for the producer. It's also among the producer's lightest and most delicate. High-toned cherry and strawberry fruit support a floral, herbal entry of beautiful perfume, the texture soft and in balance.
Wine: Robert Biale 2016 Falleri Vineyard Zinfandel (Calistoga)

Review: Soft and supple in milk chocolate and cherry, this wine contains 2% Petit Verdot. Dried herb, sage and pencil shavings contribute a savory complement to the richness of the ripe fruit.
Wine: Round Pond 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Review: Good fruit concentration meets firm structure in this very full-bodied well-extracted wine for a winning, bold personality. Blackberry, boysenberry and wood smoke meld with ample, soft tannins for a mouthful of flavor and a generous texture to boot.
Wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2015 Grapeful Red (California)

Review: Now approaching 40 years of age, this single clone, block selection is quite pretty, with Bing cherry fruit cascading into even sweeter maraschino territory. The body of the wine has a streak of cola and a nice hint of caramel.
Wine: Hyland 2016 Wädenswil Old Vine Pinot Noir (McMinnville)
